Headline: Barron's(5/28) The New Drill Masters
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Suzanne McGee   Don't try to tell Mike Bahorich that finding oil and gas is impossible. When Apache started exploring for new reserves in Egypt in 2001 after buying out the operating interest in the Khalda field from its partner Repsol, Bahorich, the company's executive vice president for exploration and production technology, was told by industry veterans that shooting three-dimensional seismic images -- a common way of detecting pockets of hydrocarbons -- wouldn't work in a desert environment. If true, that meant that the only way to figure out if there was oil under the Egyptian sands was costly and inefficient: drilling one hole in the ground after another, randomly and blindly.   There had to be a better way, Bahorich figured. He called in specialists in complex data sets to study the "noise" that the 3-D surveys were yielding as a result of shifting sands and long-buried rivers. "We ended up building a new program to analyze the data we had," Bahorich explains. The result? Apache's 2003 discovery of the Qasr natural-gas field in the area was its largest find ever, with reserves estimated at 2.3 trillion cubic feet, and the company is now the third-largest energy producer in Egypt, with production there accounting for a fifth of its production revenues.   It pays to be technologically clever in the energy business. In what is becoming a race to replace rapidly depleting oil and gas reserves, technology is increasingly playing a decisive role. "The easy oil is gone; the next barrel is always going to require more technology to extract," says Geoff Kieburtz, managing director and oilfield service analyst at Citigroup. That means Apache (ticker: APA) has lots of company in its battle to be the best at finding and applying those new technologies, from giants like Royal Dutch Shell (RDS) and ExxonMobil (XOM) to lesser-known players like Chesapeake Energy (CHK). Oil-services companies like Schlumberger (SLB) also are focusing intently on these new approaches, which range from new seismic technologies to "underpressure drilling," a way of extracting more oil from complex geological structures.   The winners will be those that can deploy the newest technologies to boost their reserves markedly at a time when most rivals are fighting just to replace production.   Lloyd Byrne, an energy analyst at Morgan Stanley, has found that since 2003, those companies able to boost reserves to the greatest degree saw an average 303% stock-price gain, while those that fared worst at this task rose 159%, buoyed mostly by the commodity price. "Companies like EOG Resources or Devon Energy are delivering the results, and investors are willing to pay up for that," says Byrne.   Still, investors don't have to pay lofty valuations for stocks like EOG (EOG) and Devon (DVN), which is why Byrne has Buy ratings on both. He believes EOG, now trading at around $75.88 a share, down from a 52-week high of nearly $80 last spring, after a selloff in natural-gas prices, is worth closer to $84 a share. Trading at 16.4 times earnings, it's a bargain, Byrne believes. He cites the company's demonstrated ability to deploy new horizontal drilling technologies to open up entirely new natural-gas reserves in the difficult-to-drill Barnett Shale region in Texas.   John Dowd, an energy analyst at Fidelity and manager of the Boston-based firm's Select Energy (FSENX)and Select Energy Service (FSESX) funds, says that companies like EOG that are able to boost their reserves at a greater rate than the industry as a whole fall into a sweet spot. "Anything with acreage positions that will benefit from the application of new technology is attractive," Dowd says. "deepwater exploration companies, natural-gas producers in the shale areas and unconventional resource plays like the oil sands will be the biggest beneficiaries."   Many energy companies believe the biggest discoveries will be found offshore -- in waters thousands of feet deep in areas ranging from the Gulf of Mexico to the coast of West Africa. A few years ago, it would have been hard to identify these fields, much less develop them economically. Now  higher prices and technology advances are making deepwater exploration one of the hottest areas in the industry. But it's still extremely expensive. "The incentive to use new time-saving technologies is the greatest in deep water, so it's where you're going to see the most rapid acceptance of new ideas," says Fidelity's Dowd.   So, which companies could be best for investors?   Smaller producers will probably get a bigger lift from technologies than the oil giants. Byrne, for his part, likes Devon Energy. Not only does it have extensive deepwater holdings in the Gulf of Mexico, but it is also a player in natural-gas shale and has a stake in heavy oil production in Canada's oil sands. "So they are really a play on new technologies across the board," he says. Byrne believes that Devon's stock, now hovering around $76.27, is worth closer to $83 a share, based on current energy prices.   Ironically, it may be toughest for investors to profit from technological innovations by backing the companies responsible for developing many of them. Over the past decade or so, the burden of research and development investment has fallen increasingly on the balance sheets of the oil-service companies: the businesses that conduct seismic surveys, undertake geological studies, develop and operate drilling rigs and monitor production. "But service companies have had little success in moving from a fee-for-service compensation model to an incentive-based model," says Judson Jacobs, director of up stream technology at Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "The big prize is the increased production that results from technology; it's very difficult to create a sustained competitive advantage through technology."   The exceptions occur where companies dominate certain industries, or show an ability to roll out a series of technological innovations. Dowd is keeping an eye on service companies that specialize in providing deepwater and subsea drilling technologies, such as Cameron International (CAM) and FMC Technologies (FTI). FMC, which is working on technologies to separate water from oil at the ocean floor, has just won a $200 million contract to supply Norsk Hydro (NHY) with subsea systems.   "It's only recently that service companies have started to get paid for their technology, and then it's only selectively," Dowd notes. "The more a new technology reduces the amount of time spent drilling," the more willing a client is to pay up. Offshore, where wells can cost $500,000 a day to drill, using new technologies to cut drilling time and boost the likelihood of success carries far more value, Dowd says.   Then there is Weatherford International (WFT), an oil-services company that boosted R&D spending to $150 million in 2006 from $84 million in 2004 and now accounts for more oil-field technology patents than any company other than Halliburton (HAL). A major focus of these efforts has been in what is known as underbalanced or near-balanced drilling, a technology that exerts less force on the geological structure being drilled and enables producers to get more oil or gas out without contaminating the field with fluids used in traditional drilling.   "Weatherford has remained by far the dominant player in this business, which is in great demand by producers in areas where they are moving from exploration to enhancing recovery rates at existing fields," says Ole Slorer, an oil-fields-service analyst at Morgan Stanley. Two years ago, revenues from underbalanced and related drilling activities generated $150 million in revenue for Weatherford; today that figure is closer to $500 million, Slorer calculates.   Giant Schlumberger could also be a winner. The company's WesternGeco division has pioneered what is known as "Q" seismic, a way of using sound waves to improve measurement of geological formations and faults. "If you think of traditional seismic surveys as like listening to a piece of music played by an orchestra in a recording, then Q seismic would be as if you were recording each instrument individually and blending them to make up the whole piece," Slorer says.   Importantly for Schlumberger, it doesn't turn over the raw data to the exploration companies that commission these surveys. "It does the analysis itself, and delivers the results to the clients, which boosts the intellectual value of what it is doing," Slorer explains. "So they may not get some clients that want the data and to do the processing themselves, but they will get a lot more higher-margin business from clients that want the higher-quality results that so far only Q seems to be delivering."   The rewards for any of these companies are likely to be incremental, rather than revolutionary. CERA's Jacobs says that there probably are no giant  oil fields remaining to be discovered -- "elephant" discoveries will be few and far between. But as even the Saudis turn to new kinds of multilateral horizontal drilling technologies to maximize recovery rates at their now-mature fields, CERA calculates that new technologies could prolong the life of the oil-based global economy.   "There is still a lot of oil and gas there for the taking -- more than many skeptics might believe," Jacobs argues. "But it's 'found' oil -- it lies in reservoirs that have already been discovered, and it's going to take more and more effort to get to the surface. The companies that do it will be rewarded, however." Investors may hit some pay dirt, too.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Follow-Up: Big Blue's Bright Prospects
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   It couldn't have been better for IBM shareholders. This month, at its annual analysts' meeting, International Business Machines suggested that earnings are poised to climb to about $11 a share in 2010 from $6.06 in '06, thanks to the company's increased reliance on software sales, emerging markets and further stock buybacks.   That's in line with the upbeat view that Barron's offered last year ("The New IBM," Dec. 4, 2006), and it bodes well for continued gains in BigBlue's stock (ticker: IBM). The shares, up 15% since our story, to a recent 105, could easily keep climbing to more than 120.   IBM plans to add about $5 a share in earnings by 2010: 75 cents from organic growth, $1 from cost cuts, $1.10 from stock buybacks, $1.20 from acquisitions and 90 cents from retirement-related savings. The company bought back $27 billion of stock between 2003 and 2006, and is authorized to buy another $16.4 billion.   IBM also plans to bolster profits through higher-margin software sales. Software ought to make up nearly half of pretax profits in 2010, up from 40% last year. Hardware sales, at the same time, should get a lift from what is called virtualization, where big computers can run several operating systems at the same time and reduce cooling costs and energy needs.   There also are some bright spots in IBM's services businesses: The pretax margin from its consulting operation climbed to 9.8% last year from 7.2%.   IBM, which in the past has pursued only large corporations, is now going after smaller businesses. And that includes companies in fast-growing Third World markets. "This is a growth engine for the business," says Bob Djurdjevic, a long-time IBM watcher at Annex Research in Scottsdale, Ariz. He also sees gains from increased collaboration between the software and services units. In fact, he thinks IBM's prospects are so strong that it should use money earmarked for buybacks to make more acquisitions.   Djurdjevic figures the stock is worth at least 125, a little above Goldman Sachs' target of 120 and Deutsche Bank's of 122. But all those numbers may ultimately look tame, given that IBM is expecting earnings gains to rise to 16% a year. Apply a 16 times multiple to the company's earnings target for 2010 and you get a stock price of 175. Investors would hardly be blue about that.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) SAP, Oracle And...Who?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   LAWSON SOFTWARE MIGHT be the best-kept secret in enterprise software.   The St. Paul, Minn., outfit is actually the third largest publicly held enterprise resource-planning vendor in the world behind behemoths SAP and Oracle, but it isn't nearly as well known by investors. One measure of the gap: Lawson's (ticker: LWSN) market value is $1.6 billion, a spit in the ocean compared to SAP's (SAP) gaudy $60 billion.   Lawson makes its money in the meat-and-potatoes middle-market, serving customers with anywhere from $250 million to $1 billion in annual revenues. It had the misfortune of going public in 2001, just as the dot-com bust and ensuing weak economy prompted many companies and government agencies to pare tech spending. Lawson compounded the problem by retrenching and failing to invest enough in its own salesfore.   But Lawson's Q score among investors could soon jump. It has made a promising acquisition of a like-sized European company that should allow it to tap new products and markets, upgrade its sales effort and accelerate a recent drive to lift its operating efficiency.   Most important, the middle market for resource-planning software, which handles everything from accounting functions to manufacturing processes, is now the fastest growing segment for corporate software sales. And it is one that Lawson's bigger brethren haven't as yet been able to dominate. "We are the real leaders in the middle market, where there is a vacuum of choice," says Chief Financial Officer Rob Schriesheim, who has helped lead the turnaround under Chief Executive Harry Debes, a former J.D. Edwards sales exec.   The stock has already attracted some notice, rising from a 52-week low of 5.39 last July to about 9-a 65% rise that still leaves it far from its 17.80 peak in 2001. Cowen analyst Peter Goldmacher has a price target of 14 for the shares, which he rates Outperform.   The benefits of CFO Schriesheim's financial fine-tuning should begin to appear at the end of fiscal 2007, which concludes May 31. After that, an improved sales effort is likely to produce 10%-12% organic growth in new license revenue (the industry benchmark for software growth) going forward. Owing mostly to the acquisition, the consensus is that revenues will hit $740 million for fiscal 2007, almost double 2006's $393 million, before rising to $822 million in fiscal 2008.   It's been a little tough to see exactly what's happening to Lawson's balance sheet in the last year or so as Lawson switched its acquisition, Sweden's Intentia International, to U.S. accounting standards and implemented a new bookkeeping system that recognizes software maintenance contract renewals with customers at a single time rather than as they arrive. The long-term effect should be to simplify and smooth Lawson's results.   The consensus earnings estimate for fiscal '07 is 16 cents a share, which should more than double to 33 cents in fiscal '08. Lawson shares trade at about two times annual sales, compared to SAP's four times sales and Oracle's five times.   Since its inception in 1975, Lawson has sold enterprise resource-planning software, which can be used to automate business processes, to midsize companies like Catholic Healthcare West in service industries. Another key customer group: governments like the State of Michigan. Cost is a huge factor for these clients. And Lawson's total cost of ownership-a key measure used by chief technology officers to assess direct and indirect costs of software-runs about 33% of that of Oracle's and 25% of SAP's. Their more complex software is usually used at bigger companies and requires much more extensive training. Some view these systems as overkill.   Regardless, the action right now has shifted to the middle-market where a growing number of companies can afford more reasonably priced systems.   With its $460 million acquisition of Intentia in 2006, Lawson not only expanded its reach to Europe but bought the Swedes' expertise in the manufacturing sector, a new market. The deal bolstered Lawson's sales force by 25% to about 195 reps, added new products and doubled its customer base to 4,000 in 40 countries.   Intentia also provides further opportunity to wring out efficiencies. Already, Lawson has widened its operating margins from 3% in the first quarter to 9% by the third. Schriesheim says the company hopes to see operating margins swell to as high as 15% by the end of 2008 and eventually to 17%-19%. Among the changes: shifting about 25% of labor costs offshore to places like the Philippines by the end of 2007. In Europe, Lawson is making further reductions by streamlining its service centers.   In light of organic growth, added efficiencies and accounting changes, "they should be able to beat and raise earnings guidance for at least the next five quarters," says the bullish Goldmacher.   "I would call last year a transitional period that has put us in position for a transformational year in 2008," Schriesheim says. By that time Lawson may no longer be a secret.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) The Best And The Brightest
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   Like musicians interpreting smooth melodies, 11 investment luminaries blew their horns last week on a stage at New York's Jazz at Lincoln Center, scatting through stock picks and riffing on investment trends. The group generally favored undervalued large-cap technology and health-care stocks, U.S. and European equities over Asian shares, and a handful of energy names.   Those betting against stocks also had their say. Jim Chanos, founder and head of Kynikos Associates,thinks shares of Australia's Macquarie Bank (ticker: MBL.Australia) could deflate. Hedge-fund manager David Einhorn of Greenlight Capital panned St. Joe (JOE), a Florida real-estate-development company, and William Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management lamented the subprime-lending risk that could undo shares of MBIA (MBI).   Roughly 950 people paid as much as $3,000 each to attend Wednesday's 12th annual Ira W. Sohn Investment Research Conference, named for a Wall Street trader who survived a childhood cancer but succumbed at age 29. A related foundation has raised millions for pediatric cancer causes and is expanding its efforts with prizes for research oncology.   The lofty ticket price yielded some familiar, though apt, themes: mega-caps truly are unloved, and the private-equity boom could end in tears. There were also some surprises, such as the observation by Joseph Rosenberg, chief investment strategist of Loews (LTR), that private-equity firms may be interested in the huge cash flows generated by Microsoft (MSFT) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).   Here are some other investment ideas, memorable musings and, yes, wacky asides from this impressive crew:   Hedge-fund manager Steve Mandel, who worked at Tiger Management before founding Lone Pine Capital, said he recently established a position in the data-storage firm EMC (EMC). He likes the company's VMware subsidiary, which produces software to run servers more efficiently and replicate machines remotely. EMC is selling a 10% stake in VMware to the public. EMC could have 45% upside as VMware is better understood, Mandel says.   The money manager also likes J&J, General Electric (GE), Microsoft and Goldman Sachs (GS) because they trade at "the same multiple that pedestrian, low-growth companies are being taken private for today." Mandel thinks Google's (GOOG) prospects look good, too, as Web-search profits are in the early stages of growth, and the stock's current valuation offers safety if revenue declines. He thinks the stock could rally 50% by 2009.   Einhorn, co-founder of Greenlight, offered up one short idea and two on the long side. He figures St. Joe shares will sink as investors -- and developers -- come to realize that some of its land is far from the beach and that a four-star hotel developed on company property is losing money. Fans of Jacksonville, Fla.-based St. Joe have pinned their hopes on the development of a new airport, but the good news looks to be in the shares, which trade for 80 times this year's estimated earnings.   Einhorn is betting on global growth via Natixis (KN.France), a French investment bank. He also likes Helix Energy Solutions (HLX), a U.S. energy-services and exploration play, which looked even cheaper Thursday when the stock sold off nearly 6% after the company missed first-quarter estimates. Despite a merger that yielded failed wells, new wells have better prospects and the stock is extremely undervalued, Einhorn says.   Dinakar Singh, founder of TPG-Axon Capital, also favored an international theme, with his recommendations of American International Group (AIG), a U.S.- based insurer with worldwide operations, and Taiwan Mobile (3045.Taiwan). He praised the telecom company's strong dividend and cited its acquisition potential.     Wilbur Ross Jr., chairman and CEO of WL Ross & Co., delivered a thoughtful pitch for U.S. coal producers. After tossing his mobile device stage left to eliminate microphone feedback, he quipped, "We are very low-tech in our investment strategy."   Ross sees U.S. coal prices returning to health as utilities burn off excess supply. In the next 25 years, the Energy Information Administration forecasts coal will account for 57% of U.S. electricity generation, up from 50%. "Solar and wind are not remotely cost-competitive, so we don't see them, however nice they are from the green point of view, doing much," he says.   Ross thinks dirtier Appalachian coal has pricing power, since supply is limited and East Coast demand is strong. He flashed overhead a list of domestic coal stocks; he owns International Coal Group (ICO), a small, West Virginia concern. For more information, he joshed, "call me on my cellphone."   Other speakers embraced technology, including Larry Robbins, founder of Glenview Capital Management. He pitched American Tower (AMT), which owns and operates cellular towers, as an alternative to overpriced real-estate-investment trusts. American Tower made a bad acquisition, is the subject of an options investigation and saw a slump in revenue as AT&T's (T) spending on cellular towers declined. But Robbins sees a comeback in 2008.   He also likes the hidden value in paper producer MeadWestvaco's (MWV) trees and forests, and Cadbury Schweppes (CSG), which is moving toward a division of its candy and beverage businesses. Robbins stole the show in his discussion of the takeover boom, by projecting a family photo that declared, "Honey, I LBO'd the kids!"   Peter Briger, co-president of Fortress Investment Group, talked up his firm's stakes in a handful of companies, including Brookdale Senior Living (BKD), a retirement-living company, and GateHouse Media (GHS), a local media publisher.   Rosenberg said he has "never seen mega-caps so attractive relative to the rest of the market." He also said that a year ago in Barron's ("Absolute Performer," May 22, 2006), but it remains just as true today.     Stocks like J&J, which are trading near market multiples, with decades of earnings growth, should be attractive to buyout specialists, Rosenberg contends. J&J sells for 15.8 times analysts' '07 estimates, below the S&P 500's multiple of 16.4. He also highlighted Loews' attributes, including share buybacks and a cheap valuation, but criticized "core" inflation measures that don't account for food and energy, and the high prices paid in the current buyout binge.   Chanos offered up only one short idea --  the aforementioned Macquarie Bank --  which has been a serial acquirer of global infrastructure assets. Macquarie's model is aggressive, Chanos says, with the company offloading overvalued assets to unlisted funds. If Australian regulators crack down, it could break the stock's momentum.   Macquarie shares are up roughly 54% since August, when Barron's penned a favorable cover story ("Aussie Upstart," Aug. 7, 2006), and the company trades at a premium to its peers. Macquarie's model works only in a world of cheap credit and inflated asset prices that "cannot last," Chanos says.   Up next, Bill Miller of Legg Mason Capital Management delivered this good-natured zinger: How could Chanos still be in business when he's betting against some of the same names that pushed Miller's returns above the S&P's for more than a decade?   After gloating about a double in Amazon.com (AMZN), a 2006 pick, Miller talked up UnitedHealth Group (UNH), the managed-care provider. Despite scandals and threats to insurance reimbursements, "financials will win out on this one," he declared. The stock is trading at a discount to the S&P and could reach $75, he said.   Miller confessed that his 1999 purchase of Eastman Kodak (EK) was early. But he still thinks the stock is worth 45, or nearly double its current price.   Ackman of Pershing Square raged against the loose standards in the sub-prime lending industry, as well as the conflicts of interest ratings agencies pose as debt is repackaged. He has been shorting MBIA, whose portfolio includes Byzantine-like forms of mortgage debt. Later, over cocktails, one skeptic noted that Ackman's five-year-old argument may be compelling, but that he could go broke waiting.   Mason Hawkins, chairman of Southeastern Asset Management, closed the day's proceedings. He offered no picks, but plenty of sage advice: Have the discipline to say no and the patience to wait for the right opportunity; make decisions even when no one agrees with you, and take advantage of others' fear and greed. Oh -- and be a prolific reader of the financial press.   Thanks, Mason. That's the best tip of all.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Follow-Up: At British Air, Time For The Seatbelts
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   Investors in British Airways know a thing or two about gaining altitude. The company's American depositary receipts are up nearly threefold, to about 90, since we ran a bullish profile in 2003, including a 78% gain since a follow-up story two years ago ("British Air Is Climbing," May 23, 2005). The ascent is likely to continue -- but not without some turbulence.   The airline, known worldwide for its British-flag logo, has joined a consortium that may bid for Spanish carrier Iberia; BA already owns 10% of Iberia. A deal could be a big boon for the British company, giving it access to Iberia's bustling South American routes. That additional business could help lift the ADRs another 30%.   But the consortium, led by U.S. private-equity firm TPG, probably will take months to prepare a bid, if it proceeds at all. In the meantime the airline faces a long list of challenges -- from shaky trends in transatlantic travel to a hefty pension liability, to potentially large fines from investigations into alleged anti-competitive activities.   BA reported a loss of $2.19 per ADR for the quarter ended March, versus a gain of $1.40 a year earlier.   Though investors may want to keep an airsick bag handy, it's too early to pull the rip cord. The company's challenges are already reflected in the ADR price -- down from a 52-week high of about 115 -- and the market probably hasn't appreciated all the upside. The airline is working diligently to cut operating costs, and next year will benefit from greater terminal capacity at London's Heathrow.   BA is preparing to take advantage of the Open Skies Treaty, which next April opens EU airports to American competition while giving foreign airlines direct access to U.S. airports outside of the big gateways like New York and Washington. BA is apt to be one of the first out of the gates for destinations like Orlando -- and there's nothing Mickey Mouse about that.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) The Striking Price: Bracing For A June Swoon
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Repetition is a large part of life in the financial markets. Traders know this and often try to increase their odds of success by using past events to weigh the present and the future.   But the past isn't always prologue, and that is especially true this year for anyone considering the traditional "summer volatility trade." Each year, usually by Memorial Day, traders start selling Standard & Poor's 500 index options. They expect stock prices to decline, and trading to slow, as Wall Streeters head en masse to the beach. Not very profound, but some of the best trades are fairly simple.   But rather than selling S&P 500 Index options to profit from the summer doldrums, Credit Suisse's quantitative trading analysts are recommending buying July S&P puts that are slightly out of the money, because they expect volatility to increase, not decrease, this summer.   Their rationale: The subprime-mortgage problem will reassert itself sometime from June 11 through June 15, when the Mortgage Bankers Association issues its next delinquencies report. Edward K. Tom, a Credit Suisse analyst, says the actual date is announced only a few days before the information is disclosed. On March 13, when the last report came out, investors panicked, fearing that the subprime mess could hobble the U.S. economy. On that day, the Standard & Poor's 500 slid about 2%.   If the delinquencies report once more has that effect on the market, options volatility would jump. To profit from this, Tom recommends the July 1475 S&P puts. (The benchmark index closed at 1515 Friday.)   For investors who don't like to trade index options, Bear Stearns (ticker: BSC) is another way to potentially profit from the delinquencies report. The firm is perceived as having more subprime-loan exposure than other investment banks. So consider buying Bear Stearns July 140 and 145 puts.   Even though subprime mortgages affect a relatively small group of people with bad credit ratings, the sector is viewed -- rightly or wrongly -- as an indicator for the weakening housing market. Investors fear that the subprime woes will spread, ultimately scaring John and Jane Consumer into keeping their wallet shut. In the absence of strong consumer spending, the economy would stop growing, and stock prices would decline.   Such reasoning might be specious, and even a tad paranoid, but those are the facts. If that's not reason enough to increase options volatility, an added factor supporting Credit Suisse's strategy is that July options will cover 196 companies that will be issuing earnings reports, many of which have the power to move the stock market, including those of Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) and Google (GOOG).   Since the last delinquencies report, stock prices have risen even higher than they were in March and investors are even more skittish as major market indexes hover near record levels. So Tom believes that conditions are ripe for a return of subprime-mortgage phobia in mid-June.   ---   e-mail: steven.sears@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Keepmoat Considers GBP800 Mln Sale To 3i - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Keepmoat, one of the U.K.'s biggest builders and maintainers of social housing, is in talks with buyout firm 3i (III.LN), in a deal that could value the business at more than GBP800 million, The Times of London reported Saturday.   Privately-owned Keepmoat is exploring a sale of the entire group or a stake in the group, whose divisions include Bramall Construction, Frank Haslam Milan and Haslam Homes, the Times reported.   According to The Times, an auction of Keepmoat is likely to draw interest from other private equity firms, including Bridgepoint International Inc., which has been buying into property-related businesses, and the rival quoted social housing construction specialists Morgan Sindall PLC (MGNS.LN), Rok PLC (ROK.LN), Connaught PLC (CNT.LN) and Mears Group PLC (MER.LN).   The newspaper said that sources close to 3i confirmed it was in "early stage talks with Keepmoat over the acquisition of a stake or the whole company."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 07:32 ET (11:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Algeria, Brazil Sign Accord On Liquified Natural Gas
Story: ALGIERS (AP)--Algeria is to deliver liquified natural gas to Brazil under an accord signed Saturday between the state-run Sonatrach and Brazil's Petroleo Brasileiro SA (PBR), or Petrobas.   A Sonatrach statement, which didn't specify the quantity or price of the gas, said the agreement would allow Algeria to diversify its liquified natural gas sales "notably in the Atlantic basin."   The accord was signed by Sonatrach chief Mohamed Meziane and his Brazilian counterpart, Sergio Gabrieli. Delivery is to be made via two floating terminals, one in Guanabara in the Rio de Janeiro region and another in Pecem, in Ceara state, the statement said.   The two companies also signed a memorandum of understanding covering development, exploration and commercialization in the two countries, said Energy Minister Chakib Khelil, present at the signing ceremony.   He noted that Petrobas has important offshore experience that Algeria can profit from.   Algeria was Brazil's second commercial partner in Africa in 2005, the last year for which figures are available.   OPEC member Algeria is a leading producer of liquified natural gas.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 15:33 ET (19:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Fund Of Information: Keeping It Confidential
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   Psst! Wanna know a secret?   Many market watchers are miffed that big-shot investors like Warren Buffett, Carl Icahn and Eddie Lampert receive "confidential treatment" from the Securities and Exchange Commission, allowing them to postpone disclosure of their investment activities on the grounds that mere news of their holdings constitutes "trade secrets." Lampert took advantage of just such a shield to accumulate almost $800 million of Citigroup (ticker: C) stock in the past year, which he disclosed only in a regulatory filing this month, when his pact with regulators expired.   Hedge-fund manager Phillip Goldstein takes the notion of confidentiality a significant step further: He argues that all institutional investors should be exempt from revealing their holdings, not merely Wall Street's biggest fish. Goldstein, head of Bulldog Investors in Pleasantville, N.Y., is seeking to overturn SEC rules requiring managers of more than $100 million to file quarterly reports, known as 13-Fs, about their positions. Last fall the money manager, who oversees more than $450 million in several hedge funds, sought his own filing exemption, but received no response from regulators. Now he has filed 13-Fs that are largely blank, hoping to force the issue into court.   At first glance, the Brooklyn-born Goldstein might seem to be tilting at windmills, but he carries a powerful lance. Last year, he successfully challenged unpopular SEC rules requiring hedge funds to register as financial advisers. In June, the U.S. Court of Appeals forced the agency to abandon the rules, an embarrassing setback for the chief regulator of the nation's capital markets.     13-F filings were mandated by a 1975 revision of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 in recognition of the growing power that institutions were attaining in the stock market. The SEC generally views obligatory disclosure as the cheapest way to prevent fraud and abuse. The current rules governing 13-Fs have grown confusing, however, as some investors receive preferential treatment, though such exemptions hardly are automatic. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) was denied the one-year confidential treatment it sought in relation to its purchase of Service-master (SVM), which was listed in the company's 13-F filing for 2004's first quarter. The SEC said that Buffett didn't "demonstrate that the failure to grant" the request would "cause substantial harm" to his competitive position.   It would be quite an accomplishment if Goldstein were to succeed in having the courts revoke 13-F filing requirement altogether, as the disclosure documents have become a prime tracking device by which other market participants gain insights into the biggest and savviest investors' positions. Information contained in 13-Fs regularly moves stock prices, as did the disclosure of Lampert's Citigroup purchases. Citi's stock rallied more than $2 a share when the holding finally was revealed, creating more than $10 billion in additional market value.   Nor was Lampert the only big investor to seek shelter by filing for confidential treatment in recent months. Bill Gates' Cascade Investment, T. Rowe Price (TROW) and Goldman Sachs (GS), among others, report they have applied for such treatment.     In his original application seeking a 13-F exemption, Goldstein wrote that the 13-F rule "does not serve its primary intended purpose of filling 'an informational void,' nor does evidence exist that it increases investors' confidence, or even protects them."   He noted that current disclosure rules already supply investors with the best indications of intent via 13-D filings that investment managers must make when they accumulate more than 5% of a company's stock.   But there may be more to his objections than his application would suggest. One of the biggest complaints of hedge-fund managers is that small investors pile into their holdings, driving up prices. Widespread dissemination of their moves in the media, including in Barron's, arguably have cost them plenty. "Why do we have to tell the world what we own?" asks Goldstein, who claims that he has produced an average annual net return of 16.3% in his 14 years in the business. "To free-ride off other peoples' hard work is neither nice nor fair."   Quixotic as Goldstein's current quest sounds, people are taking him seriously. "Normally, I advise against challenging the government," says Ron Geffner, a former SEC prosecutor. "These cases are less likely to be meritorious. But I have previously underestimated Goldstein, and I'm not prepared to make the same mistake again. These 13-F filings seem to serve little purpose and are redundant in the web of information the managers disclose."   The SEC has yet to contact Goldstein about his blanks.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) The Trader: When Records Prove Elusive
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   If points were awarded for effort alone, the stock market might have scored a winning week. For each of the first four days last week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed doggedly to intraday records, only to end each session lower.   Not to be outdone, the Standard & Poor's 500 index soldiered above its March 2000 record close of 1527 on each of those days, but couldn't muster enough staying power to finish above that mark. Stocks' volume was robust, but their progression far from elegant.   A cooperative bond market might have eased stocks' endeavor, but selling drove the yield on 10-year Treasurys toward 4.9%, up from 4.64% just three weeks ago, and the specter of higher interest rates added to the concerns this tired rally must surmount.   Snapping their seven-week winning streaks, the Dow slipped 49 on the week, or 0.4%, to 13,507, while the S&P 500 retreated 7, or 0.5%, to 1516. The Nasdaq Composite Index edged down a point to 2557, while the Russell 2000 index of small stocks rose 6, or 0.8%, to 830.   Bulls will take heart in the way stocks clawed back Friday after Thursday's bout of selling. But while the market's uptrend remains unscathed, its quality has deteriorated. The swath of stocks broaching new peaks has narrowed. The Dow transportation average has been sluggish while brokerage stocks have struggled. The S&P 500 is running 9% ahead of its 200-day moving average, a chasm that has preceded prior pauses.   The market now trades at 16.8 times its trailing earnings, up from 15.4 times two months ago and near the multiple of 17 that Henry McVey considers fair. The Morgan Stanley chief U.S. investment strategist might have nudged his target multiple higher, "but I am not yet convinced investors are going to pay more for peak earnings," he noted recently. "If inflation is falling, further P/E expansion lies ahead, even if growth is punk." But higher gas prices and a soft dollar threatens that scenario.   Last week, durable goods orders pointed to a modest manufacturing recovery. Sales of new homes jumped 16% in April while prices fell 11% -- hardly conclusive signs of aggressive price cutting to nudge inventory, but enough, for now, to allay hopes for quick interest rate cuts.   Yet another round of mergers hit the tape, including Coca-Cola's (ticker: KO) $4.1 billion bid for Glaceau, which shrewdly invented Vitamin water, and the Nasdaq Stock Market's (NDAQ) $3.7 billion offer for Sweden's OMX Group (OMX.SK).   What can shake the market out of its smug coziness and awaken its awareness of risk? Rising rates alone are not likely to prove lethal, says Oppenheimer's chief investment strategist, Michael Metz. "A trigger for a serious correction is more likely to come from some symptom of financial stress, such as a failed private equity deal; an accident in China as authorities strain to rein in excess speculation; a disorderly unwinding of the real estate boom in Spain; or difficulties for a highly leveraged intermediary such as a hedge fund."   No whiff of any of these -- yet.   Stock-market records can typically be counted on to goose red-meat consumption and overwork the sommelier at Morton's. Yet shares of many steakhouses have continued to slump, even as the Dow surged.   Weaker home prices, constricting credit and consumer belt-tightening do not leave room for too many steak dinners. All that buzz about alternative fuels has also driven up corn prices, and higher feed and transportation costs make beef pricier.   Just how bad is the prime beef shortage? Tales abound of cattlemen bringing cattle to slaughter earlier. New York's legendary Peter Luger Steak House, for instance, is cutting back reservations and booking fewer big parties. The ever-so-helpful New York Times last week suggested "less luxurious cuts" for the grill this weekend (skirt steak, anyone?).   Shares of the Atlanta steakhouse chain Rare Hospitality (RARE) are off 13% this year. Morton's Restaurants (MRT) have slipped 19% since late-February while Ruth's Chris Steak House (RUTH) has declined 16%. But what smells like a buying opportunity may remain a deceptive scent for some time yet.   Several things must happen before steakhouses rebound. Rising beef costs must moderate, and you'd catch the first whiff of that in cattle futures. Consumer spending should improve as the housing market stabilizes and as gas prices drop, but these will likely be signaled by an upturn in retailers' forecast.   Until then, steakhouses can hike prices (and risk losing customers), or swallow the higher costs (and risk losing profits). Stockholders can hope for buyout offers, like those for Smith & Wollensky (SWRG) and OSI Restaurant (OSI). And management will bravely talk up expanded "menu alternatives," even as chicken and pork prices climb. But let's face it: When it says "Steakhouse" in your name, the lobster ravioli, no matter how stellar, can only disappoint the carnivores.     It's a mystery, but what derailed OptionsXpress?   Shares of the online option brokerage (OXPS) have skidded more than 20% since November, even as the broad market surged and as U.S. option-trading volume expanded. By targeting individuals who want to trade options, the Chicago firm helped drive the option boom, and Wall Street salivated over its impressive results: More than 204,600 customer accounts in 2006 (up from 22,171 in 2002), and compound annual growth rates of 81% for revenue and 101% for net income. A 48% return on equity last year was three times that for the median S&P 500 company.   Lately, however, the murmur on OptionsXpress has grown dark and ominous. Success has invited competition from both upstarts and larger firms muscling in on its turf, making it tougher to snag new customers. The cost of attracting each new account had more than doubled over the past year to $350. And as the U.S. contemplates trading options in penny increments, exchanges and market makers squeezed by narrower spreads are threatening to cut back on payments to brokerages for steering customer orders their way. These kickbacks, called "payment for order flow," make up 15% of OptionsXpress' revenue.   Sensing the end of the line, growth investors have disembarked, and OptionsXpress might have continued its slide if not for a whiff of takeover speculation last week. Shares popped, and call options on the option brokerage traded briskly.   Little heed should be paid to such chatter, but there are reasons why speculation has struck a chord. OptionsXpress is a recognizable brand in a coveted niche. At 15 times forward earnings, the stock also is cheap for a company with pretax margins of 64%. It is also efficiently run, with revenue per employee topping $1 million last year, compared with an average of $463,000 for peers including Ameritrade (AMTD), E-Trade Financial (ETFC) and Charles Schwab (SCHW). A pristine balance sheet with no debt and more than $7-a-share in cash further accentuates its allure.   At 24.75, potentially slower growth also seems factored into its stock price, and escalating advertising costs are still well below the industry average. Each new account generates more than $650 in annual pretax revenue, and for years to come (since its customer defection rate is only about 5% or 6%).   Fallout from penny-trading also may be over-estimated. OptionsXpress saw a 5% decline in payments when exchanges recently began testing penny-trading in a limited pilot program. But it has since recovered "most of that decline" after market makers saw their profits haven't vanished, says OptionsXpress president David Fisher. "Quoting options in pennies doesn't eliminate the inherent value of our order flow," he tells Barron's. "In fact, it makes it more important for some market makers to interact with our retail order flow."   As the firm expands, the percentage of revenue from such payments has also decreased. Even if penny trading soon becomes reality, any payment declines may be offset by increased trading volume.   A recent acquisition of XpressTrade also helps OptionsXpress push further into futures and foreign exchange trading. And while Goldman Sachs (GS) previously cleared its trades, a recent conversion to self-clearing should trim expenses.   OptionsXpress also has exported its early-mover edge in the U.S. to Australia, Canada, Singapore and Europe. Fisher would not break out overseas data but says its international business is growing faster than the U.S., albeit from a smaller base. Earlier this year, I snuck into one of its seminars in Singapore and was struck by what I saw: hundreds, having braved an ungodly tropical monsoon, crowding into an auditorium on a weeknight to learn how to trade U.S. options.   Sure, management must find new ways to win customers and trim marketing costs. It must continue to improve technology. But in a consolidating industry, OptionsXpress has a big leg up, since its customers are more affluent and trade far more actively. Another bonus: options expire every month, so even the most conservative covered-call writer will trade again and again. For bigger brokerages lacking an option platform, that's a recurring dream come true.     Speaking of options, here's a handy strategy with stocks straining at record peaks. "Collars" allow conservative investors to participate in rallies up to a certain target but limit downside risk should the market slide. You accomplish this by selling out-of-the-money calls and using the proceeds to buy protective puts, so collars require little or no out-of-pocket expense.   Given the market's upward bias, call prices have become rich. And collars "are most attractive when potential gains under the collar substantially exceed potential losses," says Thomas Schwab of Summit Portfolio Advisors.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Research Reports: How Analysts -2-
Story: Following Nordstrom's fiscal first-quarter earnings release and the issuance of management's revised earnings guidance, we now expect JWN to earn $2.90 per share for the 2007 fiscal year, which is at the high end of management's guidance range ($2.81-$2.90) and compares with our prior estimate of $2.87 and fiscal 2006 earnings of $2.55 per share. . . . Additionally, we believe that if current operating trends continue, there could be some upside to our estimates, given that our projections over the balance of fiscal 2007 are based on comps growth in the low- to mid-single digits on mid- to high-single digits prior-year comparisons (whereas first-quarter comps increased a robust 9.5% on a 5.4% prior-year comparison). . . . We are reiterating our Buy rating and $64 price target.     Synovus Financial   -- SNV NYSE     Hold   -- Price 33.07 on May 22   by Sandler O'Neill Research     Synovus . . . plans to merge First Nation Bank (Covington, Ga.) and Peachtree National Bank (Peachtree City, Ga.) into the much larger Bank of North Georgia (Alpharetta, Ga.). . . . While likely not the main driver behind the decision, the move likely provides a modest amount of cost savings, which helps amid a very challenging environment for growing bank-related revenue. . . .   There is no change to our EPS estimates, $35 [12-month] price target or Hold rating.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Commodities Corner: The Toll Of Pain At The Pump
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Beth Heinsohn   Record U.S. gasoline prices are a result of a supply-demand imbalance, and they will play a big role in this summer's travel picture.   Prices are much higher and have risen earlier than they did last year, due to conditions not seen in 2006. Inventories are at their lowest level in years. Refinery output, while above the level a year ago, would have been much higher were it not for a series of operational problems and prolonged scheduled maintenance. Imports, which provided as much as one-sixth of America's gasoline after the 2005 hurricanes and helped drive prices lower last fall, are down almost 10% this year.   It's unlikely that stocks can be replenished enough to cushion against a supply shock triggered by a hurricane or a breakdown at a large refinery.   With supplies this tight, the interaction between price and demand will chart this summer's course. Motorists will have to reach deeper into their pockets or cut back on driving during a season historically marked by robust demand -- or both. "We can't avoid higher gasoline prices, and demand will react to that," says Rakesh Shankar, a senior economist at Moody's Economy.com.   If a supply shock does occur, U.S. retail prices -- already above $3.20 a gallon, on average -- could well surge past $4 unless consumption, which typically tops out during summer-vacation months, moderates.   The Energy Information Administration (EIA) expects summer gasoline demand to peak at 9.7 million barrels a day in July or August, 116,000 barrels higher than in the corresponding 2006 stretch.   Demand growth already has softened. On a four-week moving average basis, it's up only about 1% over the past three weeks, the EIA says. The year-on-year growth rate was as high as 3.9% earlier in 2007.   Some economists and travel organizations speculate that sustained high prices will blunt fuel demand. Shankar sees the economy -- the weakened housing market in particular -- curbing it, by worsening consumers' perceptions of their personal net worth, causing them to trim their spending.   Travel expenditures, including those for gasoline, probably were paid for last summer by home-loan refinancing and mortgage-equity withdrawals, Shankar says. But that won't be the case in this year of weakening home values and rising payments on adjustable-rate loans. "People can't use their houses as ATM machines anymore," he observes.   The Travel Industry Association expects summer leisure travel to increase by 1.4% from the 2006 level. Business and convention travel is seen rising 3%. However, 11% of those surveyed said that $3-a-gallon or higher gasoline would encourage them to save where they could, meaning they'd stay closer to home, spend fewer days on the road or patronize less expensive restaurants and hotels. About one-third of the respondents said they'd cancel their trip if the national average price reached $3.50.   Peter Morici, a University of Maryland business professor, sees surging fuel prices forcing tough decisions. However, facing the prospect of borrowing more or spending less, he asserts, consumers will borrow more through the summer. Home prices are still up 55% from their levels five years ago, he notes, and stocks are about 19% higher than they were last August.   ---   Beth Heinsohn is a special writer at Dow Jones Newswires in Jersey City, N.J.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) European Trader: Nasdaq Deal Pressures London Bourse
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Joon Knapen   The isolation of the London Stock Exchange is more magnificent than ever as two of the many suitors it has spurned have agreed to merge.   The twist is that one of the major assets of the new Nasdaq OMX Group -- which is being formed by the Nasdaq Stock Market's $3.5 billion purchase of Sweden's OMX exchange -- is the stake in the London bourse that Nasdaq acquired last year and held on to after its attempt to acquire the LSE collapsed.   The isolation of the London Stock Exchange (ticker: LSE.U.K.) is all the more evident because accelerating consolidation elsewhere in the sector has spurred Nasdaq (NDAQ) and the OMX (OMX.Sweden) to do a deal.   The battle for control of the Chicago Board of Trade and Deutsche Bourse's takeover of the International Securities Exchange, via its Eurex unit, have ramped up the pressure on all exchanges to develop multiple-asset-class strategies and combine technologies to cut costs.   A neat, if superficial, aspect of the impending marriage is that it will enable technology giants like Apple, Ericsson, Google and Nokia to be traded from the same exchange.   The Nasdaq-OMX deal's stated aim of trimming $100 million in costs over two years -- equivalent to around a third of the OMX's cost base -- looks conservative by the standards of previous mergers. The strong sales growth at OMX's market-technologies unit is yet to be matched by a big rise in profitability, suggesting that there's room for improvement.   Revenue gains, penciled in at $50 million, may be harder to come by. They will necessitate signing up more international customers for Nasdaq-OMX technology, rather than getting extra listing or trading fees. Nasdaq and the OMX must reconcile different concepts of technology, with the latter seeing it as something for sale in its own right, rather than part of a service that an exchange operator offers its customers.   Nasdaq may find it hard to leverage the OMX's modest equities-derivatives credentials into a meaningful presence in the U.S. But Nasdaq needs all the synergies it can get; it's taking on $1.7 billion in new debt to fund the cash part of the deal. It has $1.5 billion in debt already, and has a similar sum tied up in the LSE.   Indeed, some Nasdaq investors may be wondering what their company is really up to. Is OMX a consolation prize for failing to buy the LSE, a skinny version of NYSE-Euronext? Or is the transaction consistent with a strategy of holding out for the bigger prize in London?   In Europe, the plan by several big investment banks to set up their own equities trading platform -- "Project Turquoise" -- is advancing steadily, threatening the equities-trading monopoly that the LSE enjoys. So the pressure is on Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange to make up their minds about their futures, together or apart.   Incoming CEO Peter Loescher could be the right person to cure Siemens of its corporate-governance ills.   Loescher faced similar challenges when he left General Electric to join Merck (MRK) in May 2006, in a surprising move that, passing over several internal canditates, installed him as the second-in-command at the U.S. drug maker.   At the time, Merck was reeling from the withdrawal of its Vioxx painkiller. It faced potentially billions of dollars in litigation liabilities -- much as Siemens does as the scale of corruption within its ranks looms ever larger as investigations proceed. Loescher has been credited with helping to revive Merck by streamlining its marketing and sales, bringing in new talent and getting rid of several Merck veterans to reinvigorate management.   Loescher, an Austrian, must tackle similar issues at Siemens (SI), where he not only is the first CEO hired from outside the ranks of the 160-year-old German engineering and technology giant, but he's also a foreigner.   One of his priorities will be to form a trusted team. A good start would be to hire an outsider to replace chief financial officer Joe Kaeser. In his previous job, Kaeser oversaw many of the internal money flows at the telecom unit that is at the center of the scandal.   Another move could be to create the position of chief legal officer, to inject some fresh legal expertise into the ranks of senior management, just as Dutch retailer Ahold did after it was threatened with some big lawsuits following its disclosure of a large accounting scandal.   At the same time, Siemens must maintain its operating momentum. On this score, Loescher seems to be cut from the same cloth as his predecessor, Klaus Kleinfeld.They share the same can-do, extroverted leadership style.   Kleinfeld helped transform Siemens by divesting or restructuring underperforming businesses. Taking Siemens further along that path, while cleaning up the corruption scandal, is the double challenge facing Loescher.   ---   Matthew Curtin, who is based in Paris, and Joon Knapen, who reports from Berlin, contribute to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                          DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
