Headline: Barron's(5/28) Up & Down Wall Street: Swarm Of Analysts
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   Woe is us! The day of the locust has arrived!   The swarms are gathering. The signs of infestation are popping up everywhere, from the citadels of capitalism in our own fair land to distant shores halfway around the world. Listen carefully and you can hear the blood-curdling chomp-chomp of those nasty little mandibles ceaselessly at work. And the devastation they're sure to wreak has just begun.   These are not of the family Acrididae, that insect species of biblical fame. In fact, strictly speaking, they're not insects at all, but Homo sapiens. As their numbers increase by terrifying orders of magnitude, the peril they represent is correspondingly many times greater than that posed by hordes of even the hungriest grass hoppers.   We're grateful to the Chartered Financial Analyst Institute for a communique alerting us to the menace in all its horror. More specifically, the institute disclosed that a record number of applicants -- no fewer than 140,000 -- from every corner of the earth have queued up to take the exams that will confer the coveted imprimatur on the lucky ones of Chartered Financial Analyst, a designation so prestigious and precious as to proudly bear a copyright.   Not, let us be perfectly clear, that we harbor even a modicum of ill will against the lads and lassies eager to join the ranks of the 90,944 CFAs already plying their dubious trade around the globe; everyone has to earn a living. It's just that in these parlous times, with much of humanity already in the grip of a speculative mania, loosing on the masses thousands of fresh securities analysts strikes us as the equivalent of covering up the "Full Stop" signs at dangerous intersections.   Besides, does the world really need more analysts? Take China, where, according to the CFA Institute, there has been a 57% leap upward in Chinese applicants. A recent survey of Chinese office workers showed that nearly half of them had opened trading accounts, but only 19% of those queried claimed a strong knowledge of the stock market, while 56% admitted to at most a superficial understanding. Yet the Shanghai market is up around 50% just this year, atop sizzling gains the past two years.   Since retail investors like these office workers have been the driving force behind the great boom in China's stock market, the only logical inference is that the thing they can most do without, thank you, is professional intervention. And should the impossible happen and Chinese stocks go south in a big way, we have every confidence they can lose their money very ably by themselves.   Not being much of a linguist, we regret we can't render it in Mandarin. But given the imminent threat that prompted these musings, we commend to the millions of new Chinese investors Gerald Loeb's terse assessment of analysts (the first part of which they, themselves, are living proof): "In a bull market, you don't need them. In a bear market, you don't want them."     Pretty much everything about China, as we've remarked before, reminds us of Japan in 1989, but writ larger. Not only the stock-market bubble, but the fears in this country engendered by China's astounding economic growth and the more than trillion dollars of foreign-exchange reserves it has stashed away, a cool $350 billion of which is U.S. Treasury IOUs, that it'll take over the world. And there's considerable unease about the fact that, in effect, China has become one of our major creditors, even though, in the process, it has enabled us to live handsomely beyond our means.   Our own feeling is that such concerns, just as they were about Japan, will prove overblown. For one thing, we do think the Chinese economy is badly overheated, stoked in no small measure by foreign investment, and headed for a rude fall. A tumble, we suspect will be greatly exacerbated when its incredible stock-market bubble bursts.   Moreover, we suggest that the Sino syndrome that so afflicts Congress and even sensible folks might be assuaged by a little reflection on the recent deal by China's State Investment Company in which it plans to invest $3 billion in the Blackstone Group, in advance of the private-equity outfit going public. Speculation abounds as to China's motives, whether an attempt to curry favor with Washington, put some of its idle devalued dollars to work, enjoy the fat return that Blackstone has so far provided its investors -- or all of the above.   Whatever the inspiration, we feel that China taking the plunge into private equity when that particular investment mania is near, or possibly at, its peak, sends out benign vibes. Especially, we suspect, since China is likely to make an even bigger splash in those murky waters now that it has got its feet wet. For it means that the Chinese will be too busy trying to discover what happened to their money when the private-equity rage goes the way of all investment fashions to even dream of economic hegemony.     Unless the world implodes before then, this Friday the Bureau of Labor Statistics is slated to release May's employment report. As the big day approaches, Wall Street, as it always does, will indulge in an orgy of guesswork as to what the numbers will be. That this is destined to prove an exercise in futility will not deter for a moment the participants from repeating it a month hence.   Actually, these cockeyed Nostradamuses are more deserving of sympathy than contempt. For apart from their own fallibility -- which, since so many are card-carrying economists, is considerable --  their prophecies are prey to the even more considerable whims, quirks and fantasies of Uncle Sam's data assemblers.   Just how much such idiosyncracies distort the actual count of the gainfully employed and, by extension, of those out of work, is hard to pin down to the last decimal. But that it can be huge is evident in another report issued last week by that same Bureau of Labor Statistics (which might better be called the Bureau of Labored Statistics). It's called Business Employment Dynamics, and we'd been in blissful ignorance of its existence until enlightened by that diligent duo, Philippa Dunne and Doug Henwood, responsible for the Liscio Report.   As Philippa and Doug explain, this series reports detailed gross job gains and losses in the private sector based on nearly complete coverage "of the employment universe provided by the unemployment insurance system." More painstaking than the familiar monthly surveys of employment, the tally is published with a lag of several quarters; the one released earlier this month, for example, was for the third quarter of 2006. What it showed, though, was eye-opening.   Thus, compared with a gain for the quarter of 442,000 jobs reported in the so-called establishment survey, the Business Employment Dynamics, or BED, reckoning was a scant 19,000 additions. In manufacturing, the 9,000 jobs lost according to the payroll figures balloon into a loss of 95,000 jobs in the BED data; the improbable 20,000 additions in construction (think: housing) turns into a loss of 77,000 by BED's measure; the 507,000 gain in private services shrinks to 108,00. And so it goes. Or, more accurately, so goes the job mirage.   One likely culprit, Philippa and Doug suggest, is that curious concoction known as the "birth/death" model used by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to estimate the gains/losses in jobs from the launching and demise of businesses. Thanks to this voodoo calculation, 156,000 were added in last year's third quarter and a hefty 388,000 in the opening four months of this year. Nice going, indeed, considering that first-quarter GDP growth probably, when the dust clears, will have fallen below 1%, and April was a punk month.   All of which, among other things, solves a puzzle that seems to have bothered quite a few people: namely, how can the economy be running out of steam when there's relatively little unemployment? The answer, pure and simple, is that there are significantly fewer folks working and significantly more folks out of a job than the official payroll numbers would have you believe. The next time someone assures you that the employment picture is bright, make sure he smiles when he says that.     Another set of statistics you might season with a ton of salt before swallowing are those showing a smashing 16.2% upswing in April's new-home sales, which triggered a modest and brief celebratory spurt in the stock market and a few hopeful hosannas from the Street's sunshine crew. Presumably, that blistering gain was caused by the sharpest decline in median new-home prices since December 1970.   That spurt contrasted with a drop in existing-home sales last month and the ninth straight sag in prices. Something doesn't quite compute here, since more often than not you have to sell the house you live in to buy a new one.   Merrill Lynch's David Rosenberg points out, furthermore, a heap of the sales, accounting for 35% of the gain, were in "units not started," which he says is code for "pre-selling." Sales of completed units were virtually flat, edging up 1,000 to 31,000. Why, he wonders, would anyone buy on spec when there's a humongous glut of inventory of brand-new completed houses for sale?   David also finds it more than passing strange that the biggest part of the sales increase -- 28% in April -- was in the South, a proxy for Florida, and next biggest -- 8.5% -- was in the West, a proxy for California. Which means, he explains, that the two areas with the least affordability racked up the largest new-home sales gains. Something he frankly finds "hard to comprehend."   The bottom line, as it were, is that housing has yet to hit bottom.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Thailand's PTT Exploration Discovers Gas Off Myanmar's Coast
Story: YANGON (AP)--A Thai company has discovered natural gas off the coast of Myanmar, in the latest boost to the impoverished country's thriving energy sector, state media reported Saturday.   PTT Exploration & Production (PTTEP.TH) discovered a large deposit of natural gas in the Gulf of Martaban about 188 miles south of Yangon, the New Light of Myanmar reported. An appraisal well is expected to produce maximum 31.5 million cubic feet of natural gas per day, the newspaper reported, which along with two earlier discoveries made the site commercially viable.   PTT is also exploring for gas in a number of other areas, or blocks, in the Gulf of Martaban.   Since Myanmar liberalized its investment code in late 1988, the military-ruled nation has attracted its largest foreign investments in the energy sector.   Along with PTT Exploration, it has signed oil and gas exploration contracts with France's Total SA, Unocal Corp. of the U.S., Malaysia's Petronas, Thailand's PTT Exploration & Production PCL, Daewoo of South Korea and companies from Russia, India and Australia.   New contracts continue to be signed despite the condemnation of the military regime by Western nations for its poor record on human rights and its failure to hand over power to a democratically elected government.   The U.S. and the European Union have imposed economic sanctions on Myanmar in recent years as a result.   Myanmar's current junta took power in 1988 after crushing the pro-democracy movement led by Aung San Suu Kyi. In 1990, it refused to hand over power when Suu Kyi's party won a landslide election victory.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 05:26 ET (09:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Trashed At The Trailer Park
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Mention trailer parks to the average homeowner, and he'll have visions of metal boxes crammed onto tiny plots, with residents straight out of the movie Deliverance.   Mention trailer parks to savvy investors, however, and they see green. The parks are cheaper to operate than apartments and have lower maintenance costs and turnover, making them cash cows when well-run -- especially if demand for affordable housing is strong. And demand is likely to rise in the wakeof the subprime-mortgage meltdown.   That's why it's curious that shareholders of Affordable Residential Communities, which runs manufactured-home sites, aren't seeing red. In April, the Englewood, Colo., outfit (ticker: ARC) said it would sell its manufactured-home-community business to its second-largest shareholder, Farallon Capital Management, for about $540 million to $545 million, or $9.35 to $9.40 a share in cash, plus the assumption of debt and other considerations. The company will keep its Nlasco unit, a mobile-home insurer valued at $2 to $2.50 a share.   The stock market wasn't amused. Affordable Residential's stock fell by as much as $1, or 8.1%, to a low of $11.40, on the day the sale was announced. That ended a steady 12-month climb of 40%. The shares recently were at $11.45, around the value of the bid plus the insurance unit. The shares, however, could be worth considerably more without a deal, given that the manufactured-home sector looks poised for a rebound now that mortgages on more costly conventional homes are becoming harder to obtain.   "Farallon is getting a better deal than shareholders," says analyst Stephen Velgot of Cathay Financial. After the sale was disclosed, he had an Outperform rating and a 12-month price target of 15 on the stock and wrote: "Shareholders should vote down this deal." Later, he cut his rating to Neutral and his price target to 12. "No shareholders have come forward to publicly oppose the deal," he wrote, although, in fact, there's been some grumbling from minor investors. Velgot still thinks the stock's worth $15, putting the company's value at $870 million.   A Farallon spokeswoman declined to comment. At Affordable Residential Communities, queries were referred to company President Jim Kimsey, who didn't return Barron's phone calls.   On May 8, Affordable Residential reported that its first-quarter loss had widened to $6.39 million, or 17 cents a share, from $4.48 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier, when it booked a gain of $10.3 million, or 25 cents a share, on the sale of discontinued operations. The company has posted losses for the past five years, according to analysts at Standard & Poor's, which projects a 2007 operating deficit of 66 cents a share.   The latest red ink came even as revenue rose 38% in the first quarter, to $83.1 million; occupancy hit 82.7%, versus 82.4% at the end of December, average rents rose to $325 a month from $313 a year earlier, and cash flow climbed to $30.4 million from $28.6 million.   "The industry is at a bottom and pointed to move up," says manufactured-home appraiser Dan Rinzema of MHVillage, a listing service for people looking to sell their manufactured homes. "People [still] need a place to live." And more than 22 million people already live in about 10 million manufactured homes in the U.S., Affordable Residential's Website says. The company owns and operates 57,264 home sites in 276 communities in 23 states. It renovates the trailer parks it acquires, adding clubhouses, swimming pools and other amenities.   George Allen, a consultant who has written textbooks and articles on manufactured housing, says these dwellings now are "larger, more expensive, harder to transport, more homelike and . . . more acceptable." Allen adds that the industry got into trouble in the late 1990s because of loose lending standards, exactly why subprime lenders are having problems now. However, he asserts, trailer parks can be "one of the best income-producing properties" to own, due in part to little building of new communities, high barriers to entry and advantageous operating costs for larger parks. It doesn't cost any more to operate a site with 200 homes than 100, he observes. "You can make money almost in spite of yourself."   That again raises the question of why Affordable Residential's shareholders seem resigned to Farallon's offer rather than seeking a higher bid, as investors in Clear Channel Communications (CCU) did recently.   Yes, Farallon -- and the top shareholder, financier Gerald Ford -- control over 25% of the vote. But other holders could still block the plan, even with a $20 million breakup fee, in the hope of luring a more generous suitor or getting Farallon to sweeten its bid. Worst-case scenario: status quo, but in an improving economic environment.   Forget trailer trash. This could be trailer cash!   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : The Walt Disney Studios' 'Pirates Of The Caribbean: At World's End' Sets Sail With $142.5 Million Worldwide Bounty to Date; Film Sets New Company Global Box Office Record
Story: BURBANK, Calif., May 26 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End," the epic new adventure from Walt Disney Pictures, boosted its worldwide gross-to-date to $142.5 million, and set a new record for The Walt Disney Studios at the worldwide box office, it was announced today by Mark Zoradi, president of Walt Disney Studios Motion Picture Marketing and Distribution.  Domestically, "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End" sailed into Saturday ahead of last year's "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" with $57 million at 4,362 theatres to date.  Now playing in 102 international territories, "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End" added $44.4 million on Friday for a new cume of $85.5 million, which also stands as a Studio record.     Commenting on the announcement, Zoradi said, "Moviegoers all over the world are turning out in record numbers to see 'Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End," and we're thrilled with our landmark opening day gross.  This is the biggest Friday our company has ever had and we're definitely on track to having our best box office weekend ever.  Reports continue to pour in from all over the world as to how well this film is playing, and we're delighted that word-of-mouth is clearly translating into record results at the box office."     "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End" picks up where the record-breaking 2006 smash hit left off, with our heroes Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) allied with Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) in a desperate quest to free Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) from his mind-bending trap in Davy Jones' locker.  With the terrifying ghost ship, The Flying Dutchman, and its commander Davy Jones under the control of the East India Trading Company, there is havoc on the Seven Seas. Navigating through treachery, betrayal and wild waters, the heroic trio must forge their way to exotic Singapore and confront the cunning Pirate Sao Feng (Chow Yun-Fat).  Now headed beyond the very ends of the earth, each must ultimately choose a side in a final titanic battle -- as not only their lives and fortunes, but the entire future of the freedom-loving Pirate way hangs in the balance.  The film was produced by Jerry Bruckheimer and directed by Gore Verbinski from a screenplay written by Ted Elliott & Terry Rossio.    SOURCE  The Walt Disney Studios       /CONTACT: Heidi Trotta of The Walt Disney Studios, +1-818-560-7280     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 14:25 ET (18:25 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Asian Trader: Can Xinhua Put Its House In Order?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Within moments of my asking Xinhua Finance about its key executive Shelly Singhal earlier this month, the Chinese company shot me his resignation announcement. It wasn't even a finished press release. Singhal's history of promoting stocks that turned out to be multinational frauds had made him appear a strange choice to be running the merger activities of Xinhua Finance -- which aspires to be China's financial information and media leader, while also owning a bunch of U.S. investment research shops. Investors took a third off the price of company's securities over the course of the week and Moody's adopted a "negative" outlook for its debt, as Barron's and other publications highlighted Singhal's instrumental roles at the Tokyo-listed Xinhua Finance (ticker: 9399) (ADR: XHFNY) and its Nasdaq-listed subsidiary Xinhua Finance Media (XFML).   After publicly thanking Singhal for his "tireless efforts," chief executive Fredy Bush promised that Xinhua Finance would institute "best in class governance practices." Singhal sent me a statement saying he did not know that companies like AremisSoft were scams when he was their investment banker, before he got to Xinhua Finance.   But are Xinhua Finance securities now cheap? The answer depends on how confident investors can be in the Shanghai-based Xinhua Finance's remaining management and their financial reporting. The histories of certain key company officials do not leave me highly confident.   This month's furor was first touched off when the research chiefs at the company's proxy advisory unit Glass Lewis quit in protest of Xinhua Finance's ownership. When the resignation notices hit the newspapers, Bush formed committees to ensure the quality of Xinhua Finance's governance and research.   Confusion has followed the 39-year-old Singhal throughout his career. Xinhua Finance may be trying to distance itself from Singhal, but he has been so integral to the formation of Bush's company that investors should consider why she put him in charge of Xinhua Finance's audit committee, its compensation, governance and investments. His employee shareholdings and compensation package at the Xinhua Finance Media subsidiary were second only to hers.   Bush knew that Singhal had been the lead investment banker at Cruttenden Roth for AremisSoft, a Cyprus-based computer consultant that swindled hundreds of millions of dollars from investors through false financial reports and stock manipulation. He was also Roth's lead banker to Summit Securities, whose top broker is pleading guilty this year in a federal fraud prosecution after bilking hundreds of residents in the Pacific Northwest states.   Last week, a spokesman for Singhal said: "At the time the deals were done, there was no indication to Mr. Singhal's knowledge that they were scams."   Singhal had started helping Bush put together Xinhua Finance in 2003. Along with a Chinese language financial news service, she set up Chinese stock indices in collaboration with London's FTSE, and cut a deal with this magazine's publisher Dow Jones & Co. to distribute Chinese translations of Dow Jones news stories. In the U.S., Xinhua started buying up influential advisory services like Glass Lewis and G7, a Washington newsletter that boasts among its unpaid advisers Blackrock founder Pete Peterson and former Fed vice-chairman Alan Blinder.   Xinhua listed on Tokyo's small-cap Mothers Board in 2004, and Singhal helped it sell $100 million in high-yield debt. Last year, they began preparing the Xinhua Finance Media subsidiary for a Nasdaq-listing. In June 2006, the subsidiary's board awarded Bush with options for 11 million shares. That award would be worth $70 million by the time of the March 2007 IPO at $13 per American Depositary Receipt representing two shares. According to the prospectus, the subsidiary had one board member when it made the award: Fredy Bush.   Last year, Xinhua Finance put some businesses into its media subsidiary. First, however, it passed some of them through just-created entities that were owned by insiders and by Chinese corporations. Whatever other purpose this arrangement served, it had the effect of enriching insiders and "stepping up" the value of those assets when they finally reached Xinhua Finance Media's balance sheet. By passing a television business through a cheekily-named entity called Upper Step, the prospectus shows, Xinhua gave $19 million to Singhal and a long-time business partner of Bush's named Dennis L. Pelino. When I asked Xinhua about these cozy dealings in forming its Nasdaq-listed sub, spokesperson James Badenhausen said that the company's practices have followed the applicable laws of China, Japan and the U.S. --  as each legal regime became relevant.   The company says that Singhal became the "full-time" CFO of Xinhua Finance Media last September. But SEC filings show him continuing his SBI investment banking business for several small companies right up through his resignation this month. The prospectus also mentions a deal under which Xinhua referred Chinese credit unions to Singhal's investment consulting firm Brightline Capital, in exchange for $2.8 million in commissions.   While Singhal's major role in Xinhua Finance might trouble investors even after his departure, the company is still run by officers and directors with unsettling histories. Just last week, Xinhua Finance tapped as its financial chief David C. Wang, a fellow who's followed Singhal throughout his career -- a Robin to Singhal's Batman. In my story last week, I mistakenly had Wang as CFO of the U.S.-listed subsidiary, instead of the parent.   Three "independent" directors overseeing good governance at Xinhua Finance, or its U.S.-listed sub, all came from Stonepath -- a company now facing involuntary bankruptcy after three successive financial restatements.   One of those "independent" directors is Pelino who actually co-founded Xinhua Finance with Bush and has been her business partner since 1989. During that time he helped run two public companies whose shares collapsed amid bad book-keeping: the Fritz Companies and recently, Stonepath -- the latter of which a shareholder suit in Philadelphia's federal court alleged was secretly controlled by a barred securities violator Howard M. Appel.   I couldn't find Pelino and Xinhua Finance wouldn't help me. Nor would it comment on its current officers and directors -- citing the raft of shareholder suits filed against it last week.   Suffice it to say that this Chinese firm is still surrounded by red flags -- and in this case, they probably don't connote good luck.   ----   E-mail: william.alpert@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Barron's Online: Summer Meltdown Unlikely For Tech
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   Time is almost up for technology investors to sell in May and go away. So far, judging by the stock indexes, they haven't followed the cliche's advice.   So will they sell in June and go to Cancun? Probably not.   Although the tech-stock market is likely to follow its history of advancing less in May through September than during the rest of the year, it's unlikely to experience a dramatic selloff akin to last summer's rout, when the Nasdaq fell 12.87% from May 8 toJuly 18. Before any correction happens, bearish investors will likely first bid up shares.   Negative sentiment is hitting all-time highs, as measured by such things as short interest on the New York Stock Exchange. The cynicism looks like a contrarian indicator, suggesting stocks will rise further in the next few months. Tech investors, especially, would reap the benefits if this occurs, given that the sector has merely traded in line with the broader market this year.   The iShares Dow Jones U.S. Technology Sector Index Fund, an exchange-traded fund (ticker: IYW) that includes many leading tech stocks, is up this year a mere 6%, about the same as the 7.1% for the SPDR S&P 500 Index exchange-traded fund (SPY).   "We may well see a cataclysmic crescendo of capitulation," by bears before there's any correction in the stock market, says Tobias Levkovich, Citigroup's chief U.S. equity strategist. As a result, he adds, this summer might bring a "meltup" in stocks.   Observes Sam Stovall, S&P's chief investment strategist: "The market is like the silver-screen siren Mae West, calling to the anxious bears on the sidelines to come up and see me sometime."   Bearish investors warn that a market correction has become more likely, given the SPDR's 10.3% jump from its recent low, which was hit in March.   Inflation is "a major concern," says Marc Klee, a portfolio manager with American Fund Advisors in Garden City, N.Y. "Over the next three to six months, the greatest likelihood is that the  will be neutral , but it's more likely it would raise rates than bring them down," he adds. That would be bad for investor sentiment.   But the bears' concerns about the Fed don't seem to justify what is an all-time high rate of short interest on the Big Board. Investors sell stocks short when they think that share prices will fall. But many of those short positions would have to be covered if the market doesn't tank. And the factors driving tech show no sign of letting up: Low long-term interest rates make it extremely cheap for leveraged-buyout shops to acquire companies whose high cash flows can quickly pay off the loans used to buy them.   Crucial to the bull-market argument for tech stocks is supply and demand. And share buybacks and mergers and acquisitions are keeping supply low, says Michael Shinnick, who runs the 1st Source Monogram Long-Short fund in South Bend, Ind. At the same time, he says: "I don't see anything that's causing demand to fall off."   Says Tony Ursillo, an analyst with Loomis Sayles in Boston: "There will be a correction, but overall, technology stocks are still attractively priced."   So what might investors buy this summer?   "The further up you go in market capitalization in tech, the more value there seems to be from a cash-flow standpoint," says Ursillo.   Big-caps like Intel (INTC) and Oracle (ORCL) with high cash-flow yields, offer a better risk-reward ratio than a 10-year bond with a 4.8% yield, asserts Shinnick.   The two most interesting areas within tech for high cash flow -- a feature that always appeals to LBO buyers -- are software and information-technology firms, including Computer Sciences (CSC), which is trading at an extremely low 6.8 times operating cash flow, Shinnick says.   The key for tech is that expectations are modest, while valuations are reasonable, says Kevin Landis, head of Firsthand Funds. Indeed, expectations are so low that Microsoft (MSFT) recently attracted an investment from hedge-fund legend George Soros, who loves situations that he perceives as undervalued.   Landis likes to look away from the marquee names in tech to areas where growth expectations could surprise, like alternative energy. But rather than buy, say, SunPower (SPWR), a solar-panel maker that he considers a bit pricey, he'd purchase Cypress Semiconductor (CY), SunPower's largest shareholder. Cypress is "in the midst of a pretty dramatic turnaround," after jettisoning chip-fabrication assets, Landis adds. He also favors Echelon (ELON), which is helping Shanghai make streetlight operations more efficient, to conserve energy.   Chip stocks could show the sharpest upside, ventures Citigroup's Levkovich. Intel and others are cutting their capital-spending forecasts, and "when capital spending declines, chip stocks tend to outperform because there's less new capacity coming into the market," which helps them sell products at higher prices.   Typically, at the same time, investors start to bid up semiconductor-equipment stocks, in anticipation of the next capital-spending cycle, even if it's a year out.   Increased spending by cable operators could help communications-equipment firms such as Arris Group (ARRS), says Dan Niles, CEO of Neuberger Berman Technology Management. "There is a war going on between the telcos and the cable companies, and Arris is the arms merchant in that war," he comments.   To be sure, most everyone agrees that the LBO bubble must burst sometime.   "Long-term rates are the biggest concern I have," says Ryan Jacob, who runs the Jacob Internet Fund. "If rates were to go up, it throws a wrench into everything." Nonetheless, he thinks the risk-reward balance "keeps pointing to opportunity." He likes large-capitalization Internet companies such as Google (GOOG), eBay (EBAY), and even Yahoo! (YHOO), which he thinks would be a sensible acquisition for Microsoft.   When should investors sell? When they see short sellers joining fund managers in buying tech, that'll be the sign it's time to get out of technology... and everything else.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: B&G Holding Hedge Fund Co Launches EUR300M July Share Offer
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--An Amsterdam-listed company that invests in a hedge fund run by Boussard & Gavaudan Asset Management LP Saturday said it has launched a secondary offering to raise EUR300 million in July.   Boussard & Gavaudan Holding Ltd. (BGHL.AE), known as B&G Holding, raised EUR440 million in November on Euronext Amsterdam for the Sark Fund, a multi-strategy hedge fund that pursues several different investment strategies, including buying and shorting stocks and trading convertible bonds.   Plans for the secondary offering were announced May 2.   The new shares are expected to start trading on July 3.    B&G Holding's portfolio has gained 17.87% since the November listing, to EUR11.78 per share. The company's shares are trading at a slight premium to the portfolio's value and closed Friday at EUR11.83.   B&G Holding is one of more than 40 companies listed in Europe investing in hedge funds, though it is one of the few with its money in a single fund. The listed companies have a fixed number of shares which can trade at a discount or premium to their underlying portfolios, depending on investor sentiment and supply and demand.   BNP Paribas, Lehman Brothers and UBS are joint-bookrunners for the secondary offering.     -By Margot Patrick, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 20 7842 9451; margot.patrick@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 14:52 ET (18:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: London & Regional Heads Race For David Lloyd Leisure -Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--London & Regional, the property investment firm that owns Next Generation Clubs, has emerged as the frontrunner in the GBP900 million auction of Whitbread PLC's (WTB.LN) David Lloyd Leisure chain, The Times of London reported Saturday.   The newspaper said that the company, controlled by the billionaire Livingstone brothers, is believed to have moved ahead of MidOcean Capital and Buckingham Securities as the sale process, handled by Morgan Stanley, reaches a critical stage.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 07:43 ET (11:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Tech Trader: Sometimes, It's A Numbers Game
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   In the bubble market before this one, tech companies used to hide their lack of cash earnings by presenting "pro forma" versions of net income. Such follies are supposedly past -- but recent evidence suggests otherwise. In fact, pro forma legerdemain has moved up the income statement to the gross-profit line at Syntax-Brillian (ticker: BRLC), a flat-screen-television maker that struggled to bring off a $125 million follow-on offering of stock last Wednesday.   Syntax-Brillian sells low-priced TVs under the Olevia brand, and its prospectus shows a large profit for its last nine months. As the chart (top right) shows, however, those profits are questionable. The Tempe, Ariz.-based company has had negative cash flow from operations totaling $90 million in the past six quarters, so it desperately needed last week's cash.   Chief Executive Vincent F. Sollitto Jr. says the company's cash needs reflect its fast growth, with sales up 350% in the March quarter, to $163 million. At $6.30 a share, the market values the company at half a billion bucks. What's wrong with this picture?   Investors have wondered whether the TV maker shows gross profits only because its cost of goods sold has been reduced with rebates from Taiwan Kolin, the contract manufacturer for most of the company's TVs. Many institutions pitched for last week's offering were spooked by a recent report from the accounting analysts at the Rockville, Md.-based Center for Financial Research and Analysis, which said that without Kolin's $165 million of credits since December 2005, Syntax-Brillian would've had a negative gross profit-otherwise known as a loss-of almost $64 million. And that's before operating expenses.   Sollitto claims that all TV sellers "true up" their quarterly margins with rebates for "market development," "technology development," "volume incentives" and "excess warranty reimbursements." The only difference is that his company discloses them.   Why is Kolin so generously helping Syntax-Brillian plump its results? Kolin and its affiliates are Syntax-Brillian's largest shareholders, with an 11% stake before last week's deal. Kolin sold $5 million worth of that stock in the offering, and it's registered to be able to sell half of its remaining stake after a 90-day lockup. It may make better profits on the stock than on the TVs.   Sollitto's business could settle questions about its profitability if it could generate cash. Investors won't know for a while. "They're going to have to wait for us to slow down our growth," Sollitto says.     Shares of Open Text languished at $13 last year as investors fretted about the company's ability to sell its software. The Waterloo, Ontario-based company (OTEX) has grown mainly through acquisition. Last summer, Open Text acquired another software company called Hummingbird, and Open Text stock rebounded. Near 23 last week, investors are valuing the software company at $1.4 billion (counting debt but not cash).   That's 45 times the annualized quarterly earnings of the company's best historical quarter (to give the benefit of the doubt to the business' earnings power). But Open Text's continuing business challenges -- and its perpetually squirrelly account- ing -- leave me wondering about that bubbly valuation.   As the nearby chart (bottom) shows, license sales have gotten worse, not better. Since acquiring Hummingbird last October, Open Text hasn't disclosed sales for Hummingbird products. But on conference calls, the company says Hummingbird sales are down 20% since the acquisition. Applying that guidance, my calculations show that licenses for Open Text's other products have fallen, too. License revenues for the combined product lines were $43 million in the March quarter, down 22% from the levels reported by Open Text and Hummingbird in the year-earlier period. To be sure, license deals tend to be lumpy in the content-management-software business, even at Open Text's large rivals. In the March quarter, for example, license revenue for such software at EMC fell by 20% from a year earlier, to $68 million. On Open Text's last conference call, executives said they hope that license revenues will trend up later this year.   The Hummingbird acquisition may prove a mixed blessing. A former salesman at Hummingbird has alleged, in an Ontario Superior Court, that he was fired in 2005 for refusing to go along with the company's schemes to inflate revenues. Filings at the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission show that last year the SEC staff was peppering Hummingbird with questions about its revenue-recognition practices before Hummingbird was acquired by Open Text.   Before the acquisition, Hummingbird itself had taken reserves amounting to 23% of its gross receivables -- an enormous percentage that bore little relation to Hummingbird's historical write-offs. Open Text's balance sheets since the merger indicate that those reserves have vanished. Such pre-merger charge-offs can spring-load an acquiring company's financial results post-merger.   It wouldn't be the first time that Open Text's earnings have been of doubtful quality. The company still carries more than $33 million in restructuring reserves from eight recent acquisitions, and half of that amount stems from purchases made years ago. That makes me wonder if those acquisition charges were excessive, with the effect of absorbing post-acquisition operating expenses. I tried repeatedly to speak with Open Text financial chief Paul McFeeters, but he did not respond to my inquiries.   ---   E-mail: william.alpert@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) The Trader: When Records Prove -2-
Story: Take the upwardly mobile Apple (AAPL), for example. With shares near 112.50, selling a 130-strike call that expires January 2009 can generate enough to buy a 110-strike put of similar duration. That allows investors to participate in a rally up to 130 but protects against declines below 110 -- or a potential annualized gain of 17.7% with potential downside of just 0.4% (thanks to a slight credit from the collar).   Schwab screened for other stocks with lopsided call-to-put prices. An Amgen (AMGN) collar, for instance, allows potential gains of 29% versus downside risk of 8%, while Newmont Mining (NEM) has potential upside of 30% with 9% downside. The list includes rallying stocks like Franklin Resources (BEN) and ConocoPhillips (COP), as well as declining ones where the option market seems to be eyeing a rebound, like Limited (LTD) and Newmont.   Collars are also useful for hedging broader portfolios. With the S&P Depositary Receipts (SPY) near 152, selling 175-strike calls that expire December 2008 will buy 135-strike puts, leaving room for an annualized gain of 10% with 5% downside risk. Here, the upward pricing slant still works in your favor but is less lopsided, since broad-market puts already are in heavier demand.   ---   E-mail: kopin.tan@barrons.com   ---                  VITAL SIGNS                                Friday's      Week's     Week's                                 Close      Change     % Chg. Headline: Barron's(5/28) Many Happy Returns
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Burton Malkiel   With the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index having turned 50 this year, critics argue there are far better stock-market benchmarks and instruments for index-fund portfolios. But I see the S&P as still going strong and very unlikely to be knocked off its perch as the preeminent index of choice for the core of an equity portfolio.   One common criticism of the S&P is that it is a "managed" index, with component stocks selected by committee. But objective criteria are usedin the selection process, and the S&P is almost perfectly correlated with a capitalization-weighted index of the 500 largest companies in the U.S. As such, it represents 75% of the total capitalization of the U.S. stock market. Other critics argue that the S&P is too narrow, and that an indexed portfolio should track the market as a whole. There's no reason, they say, to exclude the approximately 25% of the market made up of smaller stocks.   Indeed, the empirical evidence indicates that returns from small-capitalization stocks have been higher than those from large-caps. In most cases, however, it is active management that produced small-caps' excess returns. Large-caps are more thoroughly researched by Wall Street analysts, leaving less opportunity for active investors. While indexing works well even in potentially less efficient markets, many pros index only a core portfolio of large-cap U.S. stocks, and use active management for small-caps.   Perhaps the most frequent criticism of the S&P is that it fails to correct for "bubbles" in market sectors. Technology stocks were overweighted in the index in late 1999 and early 2000, when they sold at exorbitant price-earnings multiples. At least in principle, active management could correct for such biases, though the evidence from the past 50 years strongly suggests that active managers have not been successful in avoiding overvalued sectors of the market.   Moreover, markets need not be efficient to justify an indexing strategy using capitalization weights. All the stocks in the market must be held by someone. Thus, investors as a group must own the capitalization-weighted index of all stocks. If some happen to hold only the best performers in their portfolios, others must be holding the poorer performer. Investing must be a zero-sum game.   In fact, active management is a negative-sum game. Active managers incur two types of costs: management fees and turnover costs. Mutual-fund management fees average about one percentage point a year. Turnover costs (commissions, bid-asked spreads, market-impact costs) easily add another half a percentage point. Passively managed index funds and exchange-traded funds now are available at less than a tenth of a percentage point, and have minimal turnover. Thus, the average active manager must underperform a low-cost index fund by the difference in fees.   In the past 10 and 20 years, the S&P 500 has outperformed more than 75% of actively managed large-cap equity funds. The amount of that outperformance after fees has been 1.4 percentage points annually. The S&P funds also have been more tax-efficient. While a few active funds have beaten the S&P over the long run, there is no way to predict the winners in advance. "Hot" funds in one period are often the worst performers in the next.   Recently a fourth criticism has been leveled against the S&P: Its weighting mechanism tends to overweight overvalued stocks. According to this argument (championed most prominently by Robert Arnott of Research Affiliates), stocks should be weighted by their economic footprint (the amount of their profits, book values and such) rather than their capitalization, or stock-market value. A fundamentally weighted index will tend to outperform a cap-weighted index, such critics say.   To be sure, the PowerShares FTSE RAFI US 1000 exchange-traded fund (ticker: PRF), which tracks Research Affiliates' RAFI 1000 index, has outperformed the S&P 500 since it was launched in December 2005. But the RAFI 1000 has a value and small-cap bias. This and similar fundamentally weighted indexes are active bets, and I doubt they will be consistent excess performers now that price-earnings multiples are compressed.   Nor are they "indexes" in the sense that all investors can own them. Consequently I believe the S&P 500 will continue to serve as the most useful large-cap benchmark and basis for popular index funds and ETFs for the next 50 years. Happy birthday -- and many happy returns.   ---   BURTON MALKIEL is the Chemical Bank Chairman's Professor of Economics at Princeton University.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Advanced Medical Optics Recalls Contact Lens Solution
Story: By Jennifer Corbett Dooren and Jon Kamp   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--Advanced Medical Optics (EYE) said late Friday it was recalling its Complete MoisturePlus contact lens solution after U.S. health officials linked the product to a rare eye infection that can cause blindness.   The Santa Ana, Calif. company said it was "acting out of an abundance of caution" in recalling the product, and said there's no evidence of the product being contaminated.   The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it was investigating 138 cases of Acanthamoeba keratitis that have occurred since January 2005.    A total of 39 of these patients were soft contact lens wearers, 21 of whom reported using Complete MoisturePlus products. The CDC estimates a risk of at least seven times greater for those who used Complete MoisturePlus solution versus those who did not, the company said.   Advanced Medical Optics said consumers should stop using Complete MoisturePlus solution until more information is available. The solution is one of several all-in-one-bottle products on the $1.7 billion global solutions market.   Earlier this week, the company said it's interested in exploring an offer for rival Bausch & Lomb Inc. (BOL), which was hurt from the worldwide recall of a lens solution last year amid links to a different infection.   Acanthamoeba infections of the eye typically occur in contact lens wearers but are extremely rare, appearing on average in just one or two cases per million lens wearers per year. However, various eye-care centers around the U.S. have been tracking increased cases of the infection over the last three years.   Bausch & Lomb announced an agreement with private equity firm Warburg Pincus last week to be acquired for $3.67 billion, or $65 a share, but left the door open for competing bids. Advanced Medical Optics entered the fray Thursday by saying it's interested in exploring an offer.   However, according to Mark Mullikin, an analyst with Piper Jaffray, the infection news "really does hinder their ability ability to make a run at Bausch."   The Advanced Medical Optics product in question posted U.S. sales of $12.6 million in the first quarter, compared with overall company sales of $251.7 million.   -By Jennifer Corbett Dooren, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9294; Jennifer.Corbett@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:56 ET (04:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: :LionOre Revises Grp Production Forecast For '07
Story: TORONTO, ONTARIO -- (MARKET WIRE) -- 05/26/07 --    LionOre Mining International Ltd. (TSX: LIM)(LSE: LOR)(BSE: LIONORE)(ASX: LIM) ("LionOre") today announces that the Company expects a 2.9% shortfall in the group's 2007 total nickel production target of 44,300 tonnes due to a delay in the target date for full mine production from the Maggie Hays underground mine, at the Lake Johnston operation in Australia.     As a consequence, LionOre anticipates that the group's production for the year could drop to approximately 43,000 tonnes of payable nickel (37,700 tonnes attributable) compared with 44,300 tonnes (39,795 tonnes attributable) published in earlier guidance.     The Maggie Hays sub-level cave operation encountered poor ground conditions during the first quarter of 2007. As discussed in the first quarter 2007 Management's Discussion & Analysis, this required mining activities to focus on rehabilitation to improve ground support in the production drives. A further deterioration in ground conditions has since resulted in a substantial increase in the required rehabilitation program which will restrict the second quarter 2007 production plan. As a result of this rehabilitation program, LionOre now expects full production levels from Maggie Hays to be attained in the third quarter of 2007. Life-of-mine nickel production is still in line with the current life-of-mine plan.     The situation continues to be subject to detailed technical review and the market will be advised should there be any further change to our forecasts. Management is currently reviewing opportunities at all locations to recover the delayed production.        Forward-Looking Statements     Certain statements contained herein are forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are necessarily based upon a number of estimates and assumptions that, while considered reasonable by the Company, are inherently subject to significant uncertainties and contingencies. Many known and unknown factors could cause actual events or results to differ materially from estimated or anticipated events or results reflected in such forward-looking statements. Such factors include, but are not limited to: exploration, development and operating risks, uninsurable risks, ore reserve and resource estimates, additional funding requirements, dependence on smelting facilities, foreign countries and regulatory requirements, and environmental regulation and liability. For further information concerning certain such factors, see the Company's most recent annual information form filed with Canadian securities regulatory authorities on SEDAR at www.sedar.com.     The Company disclaims any intent or obligation to update any forward-looking statements. Investors are cautioned that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and, accordingly, not to put undue reliance on such statements. Headline: Barron's(5/28) A World Awash In Money
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   China's move to invest $3 billion in the Blackstone Group in conjunction with the private-equity firm's looming initial public offering highlights the growing financial power of an obscure group of state-run funds that invest on behalf of countries.   These entities, known as sovereign wealth funds, may hold as much as $2.5 trillion in assets, and could swell in size to a staggering $12 trillion by 2015, according to a May 3 research report by Morgan Stanley currency strategist Stephen Jen. These funds differ from official government reserves, which topped $5 trillion earlier this year, and have been stashed largely in U.S. Treasuries and European government bonds.   Countries like China and Russia think they have sufficient reserves to meet potential runs on their currencies, and have created sovereign wealth funds in a bid to earn higher returns. Increasingly, these and other nations, including the oil-rich United Arab Emirates and Norway, are expected to funnel new money into wealth funds rather than government securities. Jen estimates sovereign wealth funds could match the size of official government reserves by 2011.   The growth of such funds is bullish for global stocks and real estate in both the developed world and emerging economies. It is tough to track the investments of these wealth funds because many don't disclose their size or asset composition publicly. Most of their money is farmed out to non-affiliated investment managers.   The Emirates' super-secret Abu Dhabi Investment Authority could total $875 billion, making it the largest of the sovereign wealth funds, writes Jen. Other estimates put the size of the fund at closer to $500 billion. Saudi Arabia may have funds totaling $300 billion.   The rapid rise of sovereign wealth funds dramatizes the shift in financial power and wealth from the U.S., the world's largest debtor, to an increasingly important group of creditor countries. But the growing financial power of sovereign wealth funds may spur financial protectionism in the U.S. and other western countries as the funds seek to buy more assets. A chemical company controlled by the Saudi government last week reached a deal to buy General Electric's (ticker: GE) plastics business for $11 billion.   Russia, which was nearly bankrupt a decade ago, is planning to put a chunk of its $357 billion of official reserves into a Future Generations Fund that will invest beyond government securities. That fund could be staked with about $30 billion. South Korea has formed the Korea Investment Corp. with $20 billion, and Australia has launched a $40 billion Australian Future Fund.   There are several reasons for the rapid growth of sovereign wealth funds. High oil prices are filling the coffers of countries like Russia, the Emirates, Saudi Arabia and Norway. Elsewhere, China's enormous trade surplus is producing rapid growth in its dollar reserves as the country seeks to hold down the value of the Chinese currency by purchasing dollars from Chinese exporters.   The most transparent big fund, the Norwegian Government Pension Fund, totals more than $300 billion, up from $90 billion in 2002. Norway added $60 billion alone last year. A major oil producer, Norway established its fund to act as a financial stabilizer if oil prices declined, depressing tax revenue. With oil prices moving above $60 a barrel and holding there, the Norwegian fund no longer needs to stabilize anything and can act as a pension fund. The Government Pension fund holds about $60,000 for each of Norway's nearly 5 million citizens.   China rapidly has built $1.2 trillion of currency reserves, the largest in the world, mostly because of the country's enormous trade surplus with the United States. China is seeking to invest a portion of those funds more aggressively to get higher returns and advance the country's economic and political goals.   The new Chinese fund investing in Blackstone, to be called the State Investment Co., could get $200 billion to $300 billion of capital and expand rapidly from that base because China's currency reserves are growing by more than $200 billion annually. The Chinese government is thought to believe it needs no more than $1 trillion of reserves to combat potential pressure on its currency or deal with domestic financial crises.   "China wants a foothold in the American economy and it's getting that via a private-equity firm," says Byron Wien, chief investment strategist at Pequot Capital Management in New York. "This is an indirect way to make direct investments."   As one of the leading private-equity investors, Blackstone controls or has a big stake in a growing number of companies, including Michaels Stores, Freescale Semiconductor and Equity Office Properties. China may view Blackstone as a mutual fund of American companies.   China is apt to flex its financial muscle even more in the future. Expect more Blackstone-type investments or outright attempts to purchase American companies. China's growing financial power could cause a ruckus in Washington, where many lawmakers are upset with what they view as its unfair trading practices. U.S. political pressure helped scuttle a 2005 attempt by China's state-controlled oil company to buy Unocal, an independent energy producer with sizable Asian reserves that was later sold to Chevron.   Similarly, the move by state-owned Dubai Ports World to buy the port operations in several American cities was scuttled on security grounds.   Where might China invest? It has an enormous appetite for commodities, notably oil, and could seek to purchase commodity producers based in the U.S., Canada or Australia. China has been rumored to be eyeing Canada's oil-sands region for a major investment. Technology companies, including those with clean-energy products, also could appeal to the Chinese.   Singapore's Government Investment Corp., which was started in 1981 by the wealthy city state, now could total more than $300 billion. Singapore discloses little about the fund, saying only that it has more than $100 billion.   Japan could create one of the largest sovereign wealth funds with its $880 billion in official reserves. Why does a country like Japan need almost $900 billion of emergency money when the U.S. has $67 billion and Britain, France and Germany each have less than $50 billion? The risk-averse Japanese government traditionally has been willing to hold such large currency reserves partly because they yield about 4%, considerably above the 1% rate on domestic bonds. Yet Japan arguably could put some of that $880 billion to better use given its looming demographic problem caused by a rapidly aging population. There has been some talk in Japan about creating a sovereign wealth fund.   Sophisticated investors are wrestling with the financial implications of the growth of these funds. "You want to try to understand which assets will be bought and sold and at what rate," says Mohamed El-Erian, the president of Harvard Management Co., which runs the university's $30 billion endowment.   The U.S. Treasury market, for instance, could be hurt if countries plow new money into sovereign wealth funds rather than keeping it in official reserves, which are invested in government bonds. The growth in central-bank holdings of Treasuries in recent years helps explain the surprising strength in the Treasury market in the face of the sharp upward movement in short rates to 5% from 1%.   The Chinese and other big holders of Treasuries aren't apt to sell them, but new demand could decline. Stocks, real estate and commodities, on the other hand, all could benefit. The Norwegian Government Pension Fund recently shifted its targeted asset mix to 60% stocks and 40% bonds from 40% stocks and 60% bonds. Norway has caused a stir because an ethical investing code for its fund has resulted in the exclusion of certain defense contractors like General Dynamics (GD), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and Boeing (BA), as well as Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).   Berkshire Hathaway CEO Warren Buffett has warned that America, in running a $700 billion annual trade deficit, effectively is selling itself to its trading partners. China's purchase of part of Blackstone may be just the beginning of a trend that could alter not only financial markets but the political landscape and our place in the world.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) The Glass Is Half-Empty
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Jones Soda's black cherry is a refreshing soft drink, gently sweet and effervescent. But it can't compete in the fizz department with the company's stock.   Jones (ticker: JSDA) shot up 256%, to 32, from August through mid-April, on speculation about a strong fourth-quarter, takeover rumors and covering by short sellers, who still hold about 20% of the company's publicly traded shares. Even at Friday's 21.24, the stock trades for 170 times 2006 earnings of 13 cents ashare, and 120 times analysts' 2007 estimates of 17 cents a share. That compares with price-earnings multiples in the mid-to-high teens for Coca-Cola (KO), PepsiCo (PEP) and Hansen Natural (HANS), the trendy maker of Monster energy drinks. Affix a generous P/E of 20 to Wall Street's '08 consensus estimate of 33 cents a share, and Jones would be valued at 7, some 65% below its current price.   A marketer of pricey concoctions with names like FuFu Berry and Whoopass, Jones also seems frothy when measured by price to sales. Pepsi bought SoBe, the New Age beverage company, for 2.5 times sales, and Coke paid about the same multiple for Fuze Beverage. Jones, on the other hand, fetches 13 times sales. These deals also mean that investors who pinned their hopes on a buyout are likely to be disappointed, at least in the near term.   Jones' founder and CEO, Peter van Stolk, 43, tells Barron's he's not interested in selling the company. But van Stolk and other insiders have taken advantage of the stock's run-up to sell shares in recent months. So, too, has Thomas Barry of the Bjurman Barry Small Cap Growth Fund (BBSFX), which unloaded its entire one-million-share stake earlier this year. "I'd be nervous buying the stock at these P/E levels with the earnings and revenue they've had," says Barry, citing Jones' flat first-quarter profits and less-than-expected uptick in sales.   Granted, Wall Street sees whoopass growth for Jones, based in part on this weekend's national rollout of a cane-sugar-sweetened soda. The Seattle company is expected to net $5 million in 2007 on revenue of $56 million, and $9 million in 2008 on revenue of $74 million. But these gains, and then some, arguably are reflected in its shares.   Jones sells 21 flavors of soda and a variety of energy and organic beverages. To win coveted shelf space the company markets its brand as a "healthier alternative" to regular pop, and highlights the move to sweeten its beverages with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup. Though there is no medical evidence to support the "healthier" claim for sugar, that hasn't derailed van Stolk's bid to make Jones the "premier soft drink in the U.S."   At $1.65 a bottle, Jones might succeed in expanding its cult following. But it won't dethrone Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, which together control more than 70% of the carbonated-soft-drink market. Beverage Digest reported late last year that Pepsi might launch cane-sugar versions of Sierra Mist and possibly other products this year. PepsiCo officials didn't return our calls.   As for other initiatives, Jones agreed last year to sell concentrate to National Beverage, a soft-drink distributor. Stifel Nicolaus analyst Mark Astrachan expects concentrate sales to chip in 27% of the roughly $58 million in revenue he's projecting for this year. Jones also switched to cans from bottles to ease its distribution in mainstream retail outlets such as Wal-Mart and Pathmark.   Van Stolk founded Jones in 1987 as a beverage distributor in Canada. He launched his own brands in 1995. While his efforts to peddle the beverages out of sex shops and tattoo parlors turned heads, they failed to generate consistent profits until 2003.   Nor are the company's growing pains over, as its first-quarter results attest. In a report last month, Luke Braly, an analyst who recently resigned from research firm Glass Lewis, noted Jones sold concentrate to National Beverage in the fourth quarter of 2006, well ahead of the peak April-September selling season. Therefore, sales that would have boosted spring and summer results were recognized last year. "The quicker revenue recognition may not be reflected in sell-side analysts' 2007 revenue projections, creating the potential for an earnings miss," Braly said.   Like its founder, Jones may stay ebullient for awhile. But analysts have been slicing their estimates, and the stock already has lost some fizz. One of Jones' funkier flavors is Turkey & Gravy soda. In time, that also could prove a fit description of its shares.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Teekay and TORM Complete Initial Tender Offer Period for Shares of OMI Corporation and Commence Subsequent Offering Period
Story: NASSAU, The Bahamas--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 26, 2007--   Teekay Shipping Corporation (Teekay) (NYSE: TK) and A/S Dampskibsselskabet TORM (TORM) (DSE: TORM and NASDAQ: TRMD) today announced that, based on preliminary information provided by the depositary, OMI Corporation (OMI) (NYSE: OMM) shareholders tendered approximately 49,762,507 shares (including shares tendered pursuant to guaranteed delivery procedures), which, after accounting for the 2,415,610 restricted shares that will be cancelled on the date of purchase of the tendered shares, represents approximately 83.5% of all outstanding shares. Pursuant to the terms of the tender offer by Teekay and TORM for all of the outstanding common stock of OMI, all shares that were validly tendered and not withdrawn have been accepted for payment. The initial period of the tender offer expired at 5:00 p.m., New York City time, on May 25, 2007. Teekay and TORM intend to make payment on May 31, 2007 to OMI shareholders that validly tendered shares. The same day that the shares are purchased, OMI will pay a special cash dividend in the amount of $0.10 per share, assuming a May 31, 2007 purchase date. Payment for shares validly tendered during the initial offering period shall be made promptly in accordance with the terms of the tender offer.     Teekay and TORM also commenced a subsequent offering period for all remaining OMI shares that will expire at 5:00 p.m., New York City time, on Tuesday, June 5, 2007, unless further extended. During the subsequent offering period, shares will be accepted for payment as they are tendered at the same offer price paid during the initial offer period of $29.25 net per share in cash. All shares validly tendered during this subsequent offering period will be immediately accepted and payment will be made promptly after acceptance, in accordance with the terms of the offer. Shares tendered during the subsequent offering period may not be withdrawn and cannot be delivered by the guaranteed delivery procedure.       About Teekay     Teekay Shipping Corporation transports more than 10 percent of the world's seaborne oil, has expanded into the liquefied natural gas shipping sector through its publicly-listed subsidiary, Teekay LNG Partners L.P. (NYSE: TGP), and is further growing its operations in the offshore production, storage and transportation sector through its publicly-listed subsidiary, Teekay Offshore Partners L.P. (NYSE: TOO). With a fleet of over 155 vessels, offices in 17 countries and 5,600 seagoing and shore-based employees, Teekay provides a comprehensive set of marine services to the world's leading oil and gas companies, helping them seamlessly link their upstream energy production to their downstream processing operations. Teekay's reputation for safety, quality and innovation has earned it a position with its customers as The Marine Midstream Company.     Teekay's common stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange where it trades under the symbol "TK".       About TORM     TORM is one of the world's leading carriers of refined oil products and has significant activities in the bulk market. The Company operates more than 100 modern and secure vessels, most of them in pool co-operation with other respected shipping companies, sharing TORM's commitment to safety, environmental responsibility and customer service.     TORM was founded in 1889. The Company conducts business all over the world and is headquartered in Copenhagen, Denmark. TORM's shares are listed in Copenhagen (ticker TORM) as well as on NASDAQ (ticker TRMD).       About OMI     OMI Corporation is a major international owner and operator of tankers. Its fleet aggregates approximately 3.5 million deadweight tons and comprises 13 Suezmax tankers (7 of which it owns and 6 of which are chartered-in) and 32 product carriers (of which it owns 28 and charters-in 4). In addition, the Company has 2 product carriers under construction, which will be delivered in 2009.       Forward looking statements     This release contains forward-looking statements (as defined in Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) which reflect management's current views with respect to certain future events and performance, including statements regarding the closing of Teekay and TORM's acquisition of OMI. There can be no assurance that other conditions to the closing of the acquisition will be satisfied.        CONTACT: Teekay Shipping Corporation               Investor Relations:               Scott Gayton, +1 604-844-6654               or               Media:               Nicole Breuls, +1 604-642-5898               Web site: www.teekay.com        SOURCE: Teekay Shipping Corporation  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 01:12 ET (05:12 GMT)

Headline: Consensus Seeks Buyers For London Asia Stake -Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The investment vehicle of Vincent Tchenguiz, one of the U.K.'s richest men, has been sounding out buyers to take a minority stake in London Asia Capital (LDC.LN), a quoted investment group whose share price has almost halved this month, The Daily Telegraph reported Saturday.   Consensus Business Group, which houses many of Tchenguiz's business interests, has been looking for someone to acquire its 6% shareholding for the past few weeks, the newspaper reported.   In the article, The Daily Telegraph described seeing an email sent by Robert Spriddell, confirming that the stake was for sale.   Spriddell is a Consensus director who stepped down from the board of London Asia Capital on May 4.   According to The Telegraph, the email was sent by Spriddell on the same day that he relinquished his post as a non-executive director of the company after less than nine months.   "We are looking for buyers of our 6% stake in London Asia Capital PLC, and also a chunk of our holding in their private equity fund," the Telegraph quoted Spriddell writing in the email.   The Telegraph also referred to people close to the situation confirming that the email was genuine.   According to The Telegraph, Collins Stewart is understood to have been asked to sound out potential buyers for the stake, for which Consensus paid 15 pence a share.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 07:38 ET (11:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
