Headline: Imperial Tobacco Preparing New Offer For Altadis - Report
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Imperial Tobacco PLC (ITY) of the U.K. is preparing a new, binding offer for Franco-Spanish tobacco firm Altadis SA (ALT.MC), Expansion reported Saturday, citing sources close to the situation.   Altadis has rejected two, non-binding offers from Imperial, the last of which valued the company at EUR47 a share, or EUR12.03 billion. Altadis had also refused Imperial access to its books, which Imperial wanted in order to fine tune its offer, saying the U.K. company is a competitor.   Nonetheless, Altadis has been providing Imperial with some information about its finances, Expansion reported.   Altadis has opened its books to CVC Capital Partners and PAI Partners, following the companies' EUR12.8-billion joint, non-binding offer for the company.     -By Jonathan House, Dow Jones Newswires; +34 619 93 39 52; jonathan.house@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 12:18 ET (16:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Microsoft   -- MSFT NNM     Outperform   -- Price 30.98 on May 18   by FBR Research     We believe the acquisition of aQuantive (AQNT) is a good strategic move that will help Microsoft accelerate its online advertising business. Our thought has been that MSFT must do something to close the gap in online advertising between itself and Google and Yahoo!, as we believed it would be difficult and time-consuming to do it organically.   The combination of AQNT's solutions and services with MSFT's advertising platform provides a comprehensive offering for advertisers. We believe that the immediate value AQNT brings is its ability to help MSFT monetize its solid lineup of online assets. While MSFT is paying a hefty price for AQNT, the acquisition is not expected to have a significant impact on MSFT's financials. Ignoring synergies, we estimate that AQNT will be a penny dilutive to our 2008 pro forma EPS estimate for MSFT. Our $38 price target [on Microsoft stock] represents 20 times our calendar year 2008 EPS estimate.     Buffalo Wild Wings   -- BWLD Nasdaq     Buy   -- Price 83.11 on May 18   by Merriman Curhan Ford & Co.     Buffalo Wild Wings announced that it will be acquiring nine franchised restaurants in the Las Vegas area (including one under construction) for approximately $26 million in cash. Considering that Buffalo Wild Wings ended its first quarter with roughly $72 million in cash, the company will still have a strong cash balance remaining (especially considering it generated $7 million during the first quarter alone).   With the company's increasing cash balance over the past years, we had been waiting for signs of management's intentions to utilize that cash to improve shareholder value -- knowing that a dividend or a repurchase program was most likely out of the question.   According to the company, the franchise restaurants acquired generated average weekly sales (including gaming revenue) of more than $55,000. This average weekly sales volume is 25% higher than the franchise-restaurant-system average of roughly $44,000 generated during fiscal 2006 and more than 50% higher than the company-operated restaurant system average of roughly $36,000 generated during fiscal 2006. We believe these nine locations will be a nice addition to the 140 company . . . operated at the end of the first quarter. Management indicated that this transaction will be accretive to earnings.   Were we to value BWLD shares just in line with the casual-dining restaurant group with a 1.1-to-1.2 price-earnings/growth ratio on our fiscal 2008 estimates, this would equate to a potential valuation range of 80-87 per share. In addition, the company ended the first quarter with approximately $8.25 per share in cash (still more than $5.00 per share after this acquisition), which could provide an incremental valuation boost.     Churchill Downs   -- CHDN Nasdaq     Neutral   -- Price 47.96 on May 18   by Hilliard Lyons     Churchill Downs is a leading parimutuel horse-racing company and a leading provider of content for the simulcast wagering market. It currently operates five racetracks, including its namesake, which hosts the annual Kentucky Derby each May. The company simulcasts its races to over 1,000 locations worldwide.   First-quarter earnings improved from the year-earlier level. Net revenue from continuing operations increased 33%, to $47.8 million. The gain was mainly due to the reopening of Fair Grounds Race Course in the New Orleans area. The first-quarter net loss from continuing operations was 63 cents per diluted share, or 17% lower than the net loss of 76 cents a year ago. Results were slightly better than our expectation.   We maintain our Neutral rating, due to valuation. We have raised our 2007 earnings per diluted share estimate by five cents, to $1.55, to reflect the smaller net loss in the first quarter. Churchill Downs shares are trading at 31 times this revised projection, above our preferred buying level. We believe the valuation reflects anticipated benefits from potential slot-machine operations at one or more of the company's tracks.     The Children's Place Retail Stores   -- PLCE NNM     Buy   -- Price 54.90 on May 21   by Sterne Agee     Children's Place reported first-quarter results of 44 cents a share, assuming 30 million diluted shares, which compares with recent guidance of 40-42 cents. Our estimate was 41 cents. Included in the reported number and guidance was five cents in expense, tied to [an] ongoing option investigation.   In its release, PLCE provided an update on its discussions with Disney (DIS) which are nearing a conclusion. Modifications to this agreement are likely, including a commitment to renovate or upgrade a substantial number of stores over a five-year period, with $175 million expended for this purpose. We believe this announcement suggests progress toward resolution is at hand, which alleviates some of the pressure on the shares.   On its call, management reaffirmed its yearly guidance of $3.45-$3.55 a share.   Although the first-quarter results were above our estimate, we are maintaining our yearly projections at $3.50 and $4.34 for FY07 and FY08, while increasing our second-quarter loss estimate to 60 cents a share, from 50 cents previously.   Our $78 target [implies that] the shares trade at 18 times our forward estimate.     American Eagle Outfitters   -- AEO NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 29.33 on May 21   by Morgan Keegan     The shares are cheap, and [a stock] buyback helps to create a floor, but we're still hesitant to get involved, given the composition of square-footage growth, difficult comparisons, erosion in . . . inventory turnover, and questionable inventory management. Execution continues to be superior, as it has been for some time, but we sense that investors will grant AEO limited room for error, given the above concerns.     Poniard Pharmaceuticals   -- PARD Nasdaq     Buy   -- Price 7.00 on May 22   by Lazard Capital Markets     Poniard [has] announced that data from a Phase II trial for picoplatin as a second-line agent in small-cell lung cancer will be presented at [the American Society of Clinical Oncology conference in Chicago] on June 3. Recall that during an interim analysis from a single-arm Phase 2 trial in November 2006, picoplatin demonstrated a 27-week survival benefit in 72 evaluable patients. The [presentation] at ASCO will include results from all 77 patients enrolled and will demonstrate a survival benefit that, we believe, will exceed the 27-week benefit established during the interim analysis. . . . Risks include limited safety data/efficacy data for picoplatin in metastatic colorectal cancer. . . . Maintain Buy rating and $11 price target.     Men's Warehouse   -- MW NYSE     Buy   -- Price 45.54 on May 22   by Wedbush Morgan Securities     First-quarter EPS of 75 cents surpassed our 63 cents estimate. . . . Weakness in the U.S. tailored business led to a [1.3% decrease in comps], while Canada remained solid and delivered a 5.8% increase. The gross margin rose by 354 basis points [3.54 percentage points]. . . . We are raising our 2007 EPS forecast from $2.84 to $2.90 and 2008 outlook from $3.18 to $3.35. . . . Applying the softlines-sector P/E multiple average of 16 to our upwardly revised 2008 EPS estimate of $3.35, we are raising our [12-month] price target to $55 versus $50 previously.     Comverge   -- COMV Nasdaq     Buy   -- Price 26.00 on May 22   by Pacific Growth Equities     Comverge owns and/or operates demand response (DR) systems for utility companies and manages their electricity loads through virtual peaking capacity (VPC) programs. By managing electricity demand, Comverge improves grid reliability and enables utilities to increase available electric capacity, thus allowing them to satisfy peak energy demand on a more cost-effective basis than conventional alternatives such as building and operating gas-fired "peaker" plants. Comverge estimates that its VPC programs are as much as 40% less expensive than building and operating gas-fired "peaker" plants.   Comverge also sells a complete line of demand-response technology including load-management solutions, advanced meter reading (AMR) systems, and virtual supervisory control & data acquisition (SCDA) systems.   Comverge reports revenue across two business segments. [One is] alternative energy resources ($17.6 million/51.8% of fiscal 2006 revenue). It offers virtual peaking capacity (VPC) -- peak energy capacity created through energy-load management and sold to utility companies. The other is the Smart Grid Solutions Group ($16.3 million/ 48.2% of fiscal 2006 revenue). It sells demand response and AMR products and software to utilities.   We believe Comverge's stock is poised to move higher as the company provides a low-cost and environmentally unobtrusive demand-side solution to meet an estimated 281 gigawatt of additional electricity capacity that will be required by fiscal year 2025.     Nordstrom   -- JWN NYSE     Buy   -- Price 52.16 on May 22   by McAdams Wright Ragen     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Streetwise: China's Name Pops Up Everywhere
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Every now and then someone on Wall Street harkens back to the old investment scheme, probably apocryphal, of a mink-and-rat farm in Mexico. The rats were fed to the minks, who were killed for their fur, and then the minks' meat was fed to the rats. On paper, the plan was flawless.   This self-sustaining, wealth-generating cycle comes to mind following China's move last week to invest $3 billion in the buyout firm Blackstone Group.   What a beautiful plan: China canprofit from the crackling private-equity boom, which itself is sustained by the abundant global liquidity provided by . . . China . . . which keeps interest rates low, which abets the buyout boom. Perpetual motion, perfected?   Chatter quickly turned China into a possible force in equity investing generally. Maybe its taste for American stocks helps explain the recent outperformance of the Dow industrials? And the surge in exchange-traded fund volumes, could that be China grabbing easy equity exposure?   As with any conjecture about which player is doing what in an inherently opaque market, this talk says more about the dearest wishes of the speaker than anything else. And right now, the focus among professional investors is on catalyst-driven investing based on a marginal buyer coming in to take their stocks higher.   Some strategists suggest that buyer will be the sidelined retail public, but there aren't many signs of this group getting excited about domestic stocks.   Another theory: The hedge-fund community, which to some degree indeed remains hedged through short positions and various cutesy arbitrage tactics, will capitulate and get reckless on the long side.   What better than to invite China, a price-insensitive, ultra-long-term buyer, into the game?   Perhaps equity investors should instead be rooting for China to keep buying U.S. Treasuries. The 10-year Treasury yield, rising to 4.86% last week, has moved above 4.75% a few times -- in May and June 2004, March to August 2006, and briefly this past January and February. Each time, stocks stalled or went into a correction, and the indexes' advance only resumed when rates settled back.   This pattern, of course, could change, and the equity market might, after some adjustment period, make its peace with 5% or higher yields, if it comes to that.   Tame interest rates are crucial if the bullish scenario of valuation expansion is to play out. Stocks are, for the moment, becoming scarcer, as buybacks and buyouts shrink public equity float at around a 5% annual rate. But the most optimistic market observers think stocks are not only scarce but cheap. They're only cheap, though, when compared to something most consider unattractively valued, like bonds.   There are fewer dirt-cheap stocks today than there were at the market's peak in 2000, as a four-year uptrend has created a picked-over market with most stocks squished into a narrow valuation band. And, unlike the late '90s, when multiples did expand in a slowing earnings-growth environment, the 20-year downtrend in long-term rates is over, and arguably could be reversing.   It's hard enough in this buoyant market to find a big stock trading 20% below its 52-week high. Locating that kind of markdown for a company with a stellar financial record and a durable brand is that much tougher.   Progressive (PGR), the auto insurer that has lost investors' favor as its profit growth stalled, is a candidate. Barron's has highlighted Progressive's impressive underwriting skill and shareholder-friendly approach in the past, including a feature in 2004 ("Polished Performer," Nov. 1, 2004) that preceded a 30% climb in its shares by late 2005.   Since then, the stock has declined from the low-30s to 22.74. Progressive conservatively held its competitive fire in recent years as Berkshire Hathaway's (BRK-A) Geico gunned ad spending and slashed prices. Now Progressive is getting aggressive again on pricing and premium growth.   The drop in the stock has brought Progressive's multiple on forecast 2007 earnings to 12, near the low end of the company's historical range and rather modest for a company that has routinely produced a return on equity of 20%.   Earnings are expected to be flat into 2008, and reaccelerating premium growth isn't easy. But after its latest disappointing monthly results, Progressive shares fell by mere pennies, implying that a dour outlook is already priced in.   It's encouraging that Wall Street has no time for Progressive. Only five of the 23 analysts covering the company recommend buying it, and six carry the equivalent of Sell ratings. The Street is focused on the genuine near-term challenges. But over a multi-year horizon, Progressive's strong industry position and disciplined management should reward investors nicely.   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Synthes' Artificial Disc Won't Be Covered By Medicare - NYT
Story: ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Dealing a blow to Swiss medtech company Synthes AG (SYST.VX), the U.S. Medicare insurance program Friday said it plans to deny coverage for artificial discs implanted in the lower spines of older patients, the New York Times reports.   The preliminary decision, which is expected to become final in August, extends to the ProDisc-L made by Synthes a national coverage ban imposed a year ago on the Charite lumbar disk made by Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), the newspaper said.   Friday's decision applies to patients over 60, which is most of the 43 million people Medicare covers. Local administrators of Medicare benefits will continue to be able to pay for the devices in younger disabled patients on case by case, the New York Times said.   The Food and Drug Administration cleared the Pro Disc-L for sale last summer.   Newspaper Web Site: http://www.nyt.com   -Zurich Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8040; zurichdjnews@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 06:36 ET (10:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Plugged In: Will Sybase Win Openwave?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Sybase could be waiting in the wings to snare Openwave Systems.   That's the word on the street as Openwave (ticker: OPWV) shareholders anxiously await a buyout for the mismanaged mobile-communications-software concern. Sybase, a database and enterprise-software vendor, emerged as a leading suitor for the Redwood City, Calif., outfit last week. The news surfaced after Openwave's largest independent shareholder, Harbinger Capital Partners, offered to take a majority stake in Openwave, through an unsolicited cash bid of $8.30, with a potential dividend sweetener. The Harbinger offer  roughly equalled  Openwave's average share price for May. But propelled by speculation about competitive takeover bids from Sybase and others, the shares late Friday were a bit above 9.   Harbinger -- a $7 billion hedge fund -- offered to buy an additional 49% of the company, bringing its total stake to about 62%. Its offer came after the fund lost a lawsuit in Delaware state court accusing Openwave of improper board election practices, says Michael Goldman, chief investment adviser for Abbott Capital Partners in Los Angeles, which has a less-than-1% stake.   Asked about Sybase, an Openwave spokeswoman said that the company can't comment on "the strategic review process."   Goldman argues that 8.30 a share won't cut it, adding that Harbinger probably would have to sweeten its bid to about 9.50 in order to increase its chances. In a release, Harbinger said holders who tendered their shares could earn additional cash dividends from the sale of non-essential assets and existing cash on the balance sheet. Still, "it was a low-ball bid," Goldman says. In a release, Harbinger said it would supplant the board and would urge the new directors to acquire BridgePort Networks, another communications-software maker and combine the two. BridgePort CEO Mike Mulica would run the combined company. (For more details, see page M10.)   That's all well and good, but the current board -- which has 10 days to answer Harbinger -- apparently has other options. When I reported that Openwave was in play (Plugged In, March 12), Goldman said he expected the company to receive interest from strategic buyers. Since then, Openwave's CEO Dave Petershmidt has resigned (although he remains on the board), and Sybase has made a conditional bid to acquire the company, says Goldman, quoting investment sources and a newsletter. Sybase's offer reportedly depends on the completion of due diligence that would identify enough operating-cost cuts to ensure that the deal immediately would boost earnings. If so, Sybase could conceivably justify paying 10-to-11 a share. A Sybase spokeswoman said it doesn't "engage in public speculation about market rumors."   Sybase isn't the only interested party. Oracle (ORCL) is also said to have performed due diligence, but hasn't made a formal offer. Oracle declined to comment. Other potential buyers that may have been kicking the tires include IBM (IBM), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Germany's Siemens (SI).   Goldman hopes the board acts soon. "Openwave didn't execute for so long, and now they have next-generation products that are ready for market," he says. "They need to start selling them." But first, the board must sell Openwave.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Synthes Shares Likely To Fall On Medicare No To ProDisc
Story: By Anita Greil   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Shares of Swiss medical technology company Synthes AG (SYST.VX) are likely to open lower Tuesday, after the U.S. Medicare insurance program said Friday that it plans to deny coverage for the company's key product ProDisc, an artificial disc implanted in the lower spines of older patients.   The preliminary decision had been eagerly awaited, and the company's current share price is reflecting a positive decision by the U.S. insurance program, analysts said last week. The decision is expected to become final in August.   It was first reported in the New York Times. Synthes couldn't immediately be reached for a comment.   ProDisc, an artificial spinal disc made by Synthes, which can be implanted in some patients suffering from lower back pain, was approved in August by the U.S. health care regulator. Sales of ProDisc - which costs roughly $10,000 - have been modest thus far.   Synthes shares have risen 6.5% so far this year, analysts say partly because of hopes for ProDisc. On Friday, the stock closed CHF3.20, or 2.1%, higher at CHF157.90.   The Swiss market is closed for a holiday Monday. Trading will resume on Tuesday at 0700 GMT.   ProDisc competes with Charite, a device made by U.S.-based Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and priced similarly to the Synthes disc. The U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services last year also rejected a proposal seeking coverage for Charite.   Artificial discs ProDisc and Charite are designed to replace damaged spinal discs and act as an alternative to spinal fusion surgery, where a damaged disc is removed and healthier discs are fused together.   Friday's decision applies to patients over 60, which is most of the 43 million people Medicare covers. Local administrators of Medicare benefits will continue to be able to pay for the devices in younger disabled patients case by case, the New York Times said.     Company Web Site: http://www.synthes.ch     -By Anita Greil, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8044 ; anita.greil@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 06:53 ET (10:53 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: REPEAT&CORRECT(5/25):DBS Aims To Double China Retail Business
Story: ("=2nd UPDATE: DBS Aims To Double China Business, List A Shares" published at 0920 GMT on May 25, incorrectly reported that DBS Group is negotiating to list shares on a Chinese exchange. The error also appeared in "=UPDATE: DBS Negotiating With Chinese Exchange On Shr Listing" at 0413 GMT, "Singapore DBS In Talks With Chinese Exchange On Share Listing" at 0403 GMT, and "*DBS Negotiating With Chinese Exchange On Share Listing" at 0341 GMT; all published May 25.)     SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--Singapore's DBS Group Holdings Ltd. (D05.SG) said Friday it seeks to double its retail banking business in mainland China in five years, to take advantage of the rising affluence of China's middle class.   The bank also said it has "an interest" in listing A shares in China in the long-term and is looking to buy a stake in a Chinese financial company.   DBS, Singapore's biggest lender by assets and one of the largest banks in Asia, will formally launch its China unit Monday after it received China's final approval for local incorporation earlier this week.   China's government requires foreign banks to incorporate locally before they can receive approval to provide local-currency services to retail customers.   Teresa Lin, chief executive officer of DBS Bank (China) Ltd., said the bank plans to increase its outlets in China to between 30 and 40 in the next five years. The bank now has five branches and four representative offices in the country.   The bank also intends to boost the number of staff it employs in China to 2000 over the same period from 400 currently.   "Now corporate banking generates 80% of DBS's China revenue. But we expect to lower the ratio to 60% within five years, after being able to offer yuan-denominated services to local individuals in China. (By then,) China's revenue would account for 7% to 9% of the total income of DBS Group," Lin told reporters at a press conference.   Currently, DBS's China business contributes no more than 1% to the group, said Lin.   She also said high net worth individuals with an annual income of more than CNY500,000 and middle-class investors whose monthly income exceeds CNY8,000 will become the bank's main clients.   Though Lin didn't specify the minimum opening balance for retail customers to obtain DBS's regular yuan service, her remarks reflected the position of most foreign banks in China.   Citibank (China) Co. and Standard Chartered Bank (China) Ltd. said earlier their regular services for yuan retail deposits require a minimum opening balance of CNY80,000.       Looks To Invest In Local Firm     Global banks are looking to China for growth to compensate for slower expansion at home, while Chinese companies are becoming billion-dollar businesses thanks to increased access to capital, boosting demand for financial services.   However, DBS hasn't made a big investment in China's financial sector so far.   "We're looking for Chinese banks or a local brokerage in which we could take a stake," said Frank Wong, vice chairman of DBS Group and chairman of DBS Bank (China) Ltd.   Wong declined to name any potential targets, but he denied local media reports that DBS is in talks to buy a stake in Huishang Bank Co., a small-sized bank in central China's Anhui province.   Jethro Lau, deputy country head of the bank's China unit,  said the bank "has an interest in listing A shares in China."   Lau's comments come after Hong Kong & Shanghai Banking Corp., the largest foreign bank in China, earlier this month reiterated its goal to list shares on the mainland.   "A China listing is an option that the bank is prepared to explore in the long term but not in the immediate future," DBS said in a statement Saturday.   -Rose Yu contributed to this story, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; rose.yu@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 04:37 ET (08:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: :Merlyn Med Signs Distribution Pact With Suzuken
Story: Merlyn Medical Signs Reciprocal USA-Japan Distribution Agreements     TUSTIN, Calif., May 26 /PRNewswire/ -- Merlyn Medical has announced the signing of an agreement appointing Suzuken Co., Ltd., Nagoya, sole Japanese distributor for Merlyn's line of airway management products. In reciprocal agreements, Merlyn will be worldwide distributor for several products manufactured by Kenzmedico, Suzuken's medical device division, and Elltec, Japan's leading manufacturer of infusion/blood warmers.   Suzuken will distribute Merlyn's patented, proprietary EndoFlex(R) endotracheal tubes which have a flexible distal tip that can be adjusted when needed; EndoMask(R) laryngeal masks; and EndoTube(R), a full line of standard tracheal tubes.   The Merlyn airway products will be launched at the Japanese Society of Anesthesiologists Conference in Sapporo on May 31, 2007, according to Jay Kotin, Merlyn Medical president.   A US$12 billion company with 11,000 employees, Suzuken is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.   "Suzuken continuously searches worldwide for superior-quality, scientifically-sound medical devices which will be of value to the Japanese healthcare market. We believe that Merlyn's EndoFlex, and other airway management products, will lead to better, safer health care for patients in Japan," said Nobuo Suzuki, Suzuken director and general manager of product development and marketing.   Merlyn Medical will distribute the Kenz patented stereophonic stethoscope and a line of proprietary fitness monitors, including dedicated Physical Activity Analysis Software (PAAS) that charts and analyzes energy expenditure and duration data at nine intensity levels for up to 200 days.   In a related agreement, Kotin has announced that his company will also distribute a group of blood and fluid warmers manufactured by Elltec, Co., Ltd., also headquartered in Nagoya. The agreement includes worldwide distributorship of the revolutionary new FlexWarmer(R) which requires neither battery nor electric power.   Merlyn Medical is a full-service medical innovator, developer, manufacturer and marketer headquartered in Tustin, CA. Merlyn products are distributed by leading medical device firms worldwide. Additional information is available at www.MerlynMedical.com.    SOURCE  Merlyn Medical         /CONTACT: Nancy Hoover, +1-619-988-6978 - mobile, nhoover@usa.net, for Merlyn Medical      /Web site: http://www.MerlynMedical.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 15:59 ET (19:59 GMT)

Headline: AEM Asks ASM Hldr To Respect Merger Talks Confidentiality
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--AEM SpA (AEM.MI), Italy's biggest municipal utility in terms of capacity, has asked the controlling shareholder of rival ASM SpA (ASM.MI) to adhere to its confidentiality agreement in the merger talks between the two companies.   AEM, which supplies power and natural gas to the city of Milan, also said in a statement issued Friday that the negotiations between the two utilities are still ongoing and not finalized.   AEM said it made the statement following local media reports citing comments from Mayor Paolo Corsini of the city of Brescia, which controls ASM with a 69% stake.   AEM is controlled by Milan's City Hall with a 43% stake.   Corsini was reported telling representatives of the municipality Friday the merger details will be approved by the middle of June.   The mayor said the municipalities of Brescia and Milan will have a combined 55% stake, to be equally split between the two, in the combined utility.   Corsini added that as part of the deal, AEM will incorporate waste company Amsa to boost its value, while ASM shareholders will receive an unspecified extraordinary dividend. Furthermore, Milan City Hall has agreed not to exercise a convertible bond for AEM shares.   Brescia's mayor also told the city council that the new company will have a dual corporate governance structure with a supervisory board and a management one. He didn't give details on the controversial issue of the share swap ratio between ASM and AEM.   AEM shares closed Friday at EUR2.807, down 0.3%, while those of ASM were at EUR4.785, or 1% higher, in a slightly higher overall market.   AEM said in its statement "some" of Corsini's comments are incorrect, but didn't specify which ones.   AEM and ASM have been in tie-up talks since last summer that would create a utility with a market value of more than EUR8.5 billion.     -Liam Moloney, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 678 2543; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 08:17 ET (12:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. Once Again Named One of the Top Performing Companies in Massachusetts
Story: PITTSFIELD, Mass.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 26, 2007--   Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. (the "Company") (NASDAQ: BHLB), the holding company for Berkshire Bank (the "Bank") announced today that it has been ranked by The Boston Globe as one of the 100 top performing Massachusetts-based public companies for the seventh year in a row. The Company is one of six financial services companies in Massachusetts and one of only two companies in Western Massachusetts that were selected for this honor. In addition, the Company is the only public company selected from Berkshire County.     Commenting on this announcement, Michael P. Daly, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company and the Bank said, "With all the high performing publicly-held companies in Massachusetts, it is once again an honor for us to be recognized by The Boston Globe. We are executing on our strategy of transforming our primary subsidiary, Berkshire Bank, into a regional bank. We now have 31 full-service branches and 41 ATMs throughout Berkshire, Hampden and Hampshire Counties in Western Massachusetts and Northeastern New York. In addition to insurance and investment services that include the largest insurance agency headquartered in Western Massachusetts with 10 locations and a wealth management group with a dedicated in-house investment team with over $500 million in assets under management."     Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. is the holding company for Berkshire Bank - America's Most Exciting Bank(SM). Established in 1846, Berkshire Bank is one of Massachusetts' oldest and largest independent banks and the largest banking institution based in Western Massachusetts. The Bank is headquartered in Pittsfield, Massachusetts with branches serving communities throughout Western Massachusetts and Northeastern New York. The Bank is transitioning into a regional bank, delivering exceptional customer service and a broad array of competitively priced deposit, loan, insurance, wealth management and trust services and investment products. For more information on Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. or Berkshire Bank, visit www.berkshirebank.com or call 800-773-5601.        CONTACT: Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. & Berkshire Bank               Michael P. Daly, 413-236-3194               President & CEO        SOURCE: Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc.  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 11:15 ET (15:15 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/28) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from May 17 through 23.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Texas Pacific Land Trust (TPL)   Mercury Real Estate Advisors called for the company to accelerate its stock-buyback program. Mercury also said that Texas Pacific should split its subshares, 10-for-1, to "create greater liquidity and round-lot affordability" for them. "We are tremendous believers" in Texas Pacific's "valuable assets and business plan." However, Mercury wants "more aggressive implementation" of the buyback. Mercury currently holds 171,887 shares (8.1% of the total outstanding).     Claxson Interactive Group (XSONF)   Black Horse Capital Management boosted its stake to 2,036,121 shares (9.4%) by buying 224,901 from April 18 to May 18 at prices that ranged from $12 to $12.75. In the past, Black Horse has said that a proposed buyout offer by Claxson's controlling shareholders is "entirely inadequate," and it urged the company's board to reject the bid. A special committee of independent directors was formed to evaluate the proposal.     MGM Mirage (MGM)   Billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. intends to enter into negotiations with MGM to purchase the entertainment and gaming company's Bellagio Hotel and Casino and City Center properties. Tracinda said it also wishes to pursue strategic alternatives with respect to its investment in MGM, the world's second-largest casino operator. These might include a financial restructuring involving all or a substantial portion of the remainder of the company. Tracinda owns 158.8 million shares (56%).     Arrow International (ARRO)   Shareholder Robert W. Cruickshank intends to nominate five additional directors, including himself, for election to the company's board. One of his nominees will be Richard T. Niner. Earlier this month, Niner, who was a member of Arrow's board for 25 years, resigned amid concern over why the directors have decided to explore a sale. The annual meeting is scheduled for July 17. Cruickshank has 4,624,494 shares (10.3%).     Scottish Re Group (SCT)   MassMutual Capital Partners said it had nominated a slate of directors, including Jonathan Bloomer, Christopher Brody, James Butler, James Chapman, Thomas Finke, Robert Joyal, Larry Port, Michael Rollings and Lenard Tessler. MassMutual Capital holds 75 million shares (34.4%).     LNB Bancorp (LNBB)   AMG Investments said that it's concerned about the company's loans to its officers and directors. AMG contends that LNB, the holding company for Lorain National Bank, had outstanding loans to related parties of almost $25 million at the end of 2006, representing nearly 4% of the company's net loan portfolio. AMG said that such loan exposure to insiders is unusual at similar banks.  AMG added that is is disappointed in the company's performance and believes that it is imperative for management and the board to take immediate steps to maximize shareholder value. AMG Investments owns 533,681 shares (8.3%).     Increases in Holdings     Biosite (BSTE)   Funds including Mario Gabelli's Gamco Investors (GBL) increased their position to 1,506,034 shares (8.81%).     Decreases in Holdings     VistaCare (VSTA)   Investor Philip Timon lowered his stake to 2.49 million shares (14.9%) from the 3.18 million (19.4%) he had reported on Jan. 8.     US 1 Industries (USOO)   A group including Loeb Partners trimmed its stake to 794,896 shares (6.53%) by selling 144,900 from March 19 to May 18 at $1.39 to $1.94 per share.     Nymex Holdings (NMX)   Private-equity firm General Atlantic cut its holdings to 6,259,100 shares (6.8%) by selling1,888,100 from March 27 to May 17 at prices ranging from $123.00 to $133.36.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/28) Follow-Up: Summer Bleach Party
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   The cleanup has begun. At Clorox's much-awaited analysts' meeting last week, Chief Executive Donald Knauss outlined a series of steps to boost profitability, including expanding the company's international strategy, taking a hard look at divisions that fail to meet new profitability hurdles, and launching two new products that may be the "game changers" investors have anticipated for more than a year.   Green Works, a line of plant-based cleaning products, is now beingtest-marketed in northern California. And come July, Clorox will roll out a line of Glad bags designed to let consumers safely steam food in the microwave.   Separately, Knauss said in an interview that the company is firming up plans to push into China and Brazil. "I would hope that in the next 12 months our China strategy will be well known," he said, adding that he intends to announce Clorox's Brazil strategy in the first half of fiscal '08.   The flurry of news did little to help Clorox's stock (ticker: CLX). It was  trading Friday at about 66, just below the 67 it fetched when we wrote a preview of Clorox's plans last week ("How Clorox Could Clean Up," May 21).   It's no mystery why investors are showing restraint. Clorox said earnings for next year, which it dubbed a "transition year," will be hurt by restructuring charges and plant closures. For the fiscal year ending June 2008, excluding charges, Clorox expects earnings of $3.52 to $3.67 a share, versus an estimated $3.21 to $3.27 a share this year. It also announced that it may boost debt, as it ramps up stock repurchases and boosts its dividend. As a result, analysts cut forecasts and bond specialists like Gimme Credit shook their heads.   But Clorox is focusing intently on margin improvement, giving hard looks at less profitable lines such as charcoal, Armor All auto products and Brita water purification. Bob Goldsborough, who looks after Ariel Capital Management's Clorox position, believes the stock is worth $85.   Still, he and others would like to see the pace of change pick up. If only it could happen as fast as bleach removes spots.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: KKR Mulls IPO But Will Await Blackstone Debut - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (KKR.XX), the U.S. private equity group, is contemplating an initial public offering but will wait until rival Blackstone Group (BGP.XX) has floated before pressing ahead, The Times of London reported Saturday.   According to the newspaper, Henry Kravis, a founding partner of the firm, told investors at a conference this week that it would be irresponsible for KKR not to consider floating shares as a way of unlocking value from the closely held buyout group.   Although KKR has not made a firm decision to push ahead with a float, the Times reported Kravis saying that the group would report to shareholders with a decision once Blackstone had gone to market.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 26, 2007 07:25 ET (11:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
